  • However, the presence of withdrawal bleeding does not provide information about the status of the pituitary-gonadal axis, as this bleed is primarily a test of endometrial and ovarian estrogen function rather than a direct assessment of pituitary function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of pregnancy: Withdrawal bleeding confirms that the patient is not pregnant, as pregnancy would typically prevent the endometrial response seen in withdrawal bleeding.


Option B. Production of endogenous estrogen: The occurrence of withdrawal bleeding indicates that there is enough endogenous estrogen to sensitize the endometrium to progesterone, which is essential for the bleed to occur.


Option C. Endometrium is responsive to estrogen: Withdrawal bleeding signifies that the endometrium has been sufficiently primed by estrogen to respond to the withdrawal of progestogen, indicating its responsiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Withdrawal bleeding following progestogen administration in a case of secondary amenorrhea suggests adequate endogenous estrogen levels and a responsive endometrium but does not inherently diagnose issues within the pituitary-gonadal axis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurred vision and photophobia. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist notes some changes in the subretinal space as shown below. Which of the following types of nodules are most likely being observed in this patient's examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dalen-Fuchs nodules

 

  • Dalen-Fuchs nodules are characteristic of sympathetic ophthalmia and represent accumulations of inflammatory cells between the Bruch's membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • These nodules appear as discrete, yellowish-white lesions and are indicative of chronic intraocular inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busacca nodules: Busacca nodules are found on the iris surface and are associated with granulomatous uveitis, not typically seen in the subretinal space.

 

Option C. Lisch nodules: Lisch nodules are melanocytic hamartomas that appear on the iris and are commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.

 

Option D. Koeppe's nodules: Koeppe's nodules are also associated with granulomatous uveitis but are located at the pupillary margin of the iris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognizing Dalen-Fuchs nodules in the subretinal space is crucial for diagnosing sympathetic ophthalmia, a rare but serious autoimmune condition that can lead to bilateral eye inflammation following trauma to one eye.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman seeks consultation for reversal of her previous tubal ligation. She wishes to understand which surgical procedure offers the highest likelihood of successful recanalization. Which of the following procedures is associated with the highest chance of recanalization during surgery for reversal of tubal ligation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isthmo-isthmic anastomosis

 

  • Isthmo-isthmic anastomosis involves connecting the isthmic sections of the fallopian tubes and is generally associated with the highest success rates for recanalization after tubal ligation reversal.
  • This part of the tube has a similar diameter and muscular structure, which tends to heal well and support tubal function after anastomosis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Isthmo-ampullary anastomosis: This involves connecting the isthmus of one tube to the ampulla of the other, which may have differing diameters and tissue characteristics, potentially lowering the success rate of recanalization.


Option C. Ampullo-ampullary anastomosis: This type connects two ampullary sections, which are wider and less muscular than the isthmus, possibly affecting the success rates due to the less robust nature of the ampullary tissue.


Option D. Cornual obstruction: This refers to a blockage at the junction where the fallopian tube meets the uterus and is not typically associated with high recanalization rates in the context of reversing tubal ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When considering tubal ligation reversal, it is important to understand that the type of anastomosis performed can greatly influence the likelihood of successful recanalization, with isthmo-isthmic anastomosis generally offering the best outcomes.

choices.text: Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm
Myelin figures in the cytoplasm
Parallel rays of tubular structures in lysosomes
Electron dense deposit in the mitochondria

questions.text: A one-year-old boy presented with hepatosplenomegaly and delayed milestones. Liver biopsy and bone marrow biopsy showed histiocytes with PAS-positive Diastase-resistant material in the cytoplasm. What is most likely to be seen in the electron-microscopic examination of these histiocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm

 

  • The presence of PAS-positive Diastase-resistant material in the cytoplasm of histiocytes is characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
  • Birbeck granules are a hallmark of LCH and are identified by their unique tennis racket shape or rod shape with a zipper-like structure on electron microscopy.
  • These granules are found in the cytoplasm of Langerhans cells, which are a type of histiocyte.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myelin figures in the cytoplasm: These are usually found in cells undergoing apoptosis or necrosis and are not specific to LCH.

 

Option C. Parallel rays of tubular structures in lysosomes: This description does not match the characteristic Birbeck granules of LCH and is more commonly associated with other storage diseases.

 

Option D. Electron dense deposit in the mitochondria: These are seen in mitochondrial disorders and are not related to the histiocytic disorders like LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Birbeck granules, identified on electron microscopy, are pathognomonic for Langerhans cell histiocytosis when found within histiocytes that exhibit PAS-positive Diastase-resistant material.

choices.text: Traction, POP, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation
Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP
Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP
Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after slipping and falling at home. She complains of severe pain and deformity in her wrist. Radiographs confirm a Colles' fracture. You decide to manage the fracture with a Plaster of Paris (POP) cast. Which of the following is the correct sequence of reduction maneuvers to properly align the fracture before applying the cast?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP

 

  • The correct sequence of reduction for a Colles' fracture involves several specific steps to ensure the bone is realigned properly before immobilization. 
  • Initially, traction is applied to counteract the deformity and align the fracture fragments. 
  • Following traction, palmar flexion is performed. This step corrects the dorsal angulation typically seen in Colles' fractures. 
  • After achieving palmar flexion, ulnar deviation is applied, which corrects the radial deviation of the wrist that often accompanies these fractures. 
  • Finally, a Plaster of Paris (POP) cast is applied to stabilize and immobilize the fracture in the corrected position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Traction, POP, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation: This sequence is incorrect as the cast (POP) is applied after the reduction maneuvers are complete to maintain the alignment.

 

Option C. Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP: This sequence incorrectly orders palmar flexion after ulnar deviation, which may not effectively correct the typical deformity of a Colles' fracture. Palmar flexion is typically performed first to address the primary dorsal displacement before fine-tuning with ulnar deviation.

 

Option D. Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP: This sequence begins with palmar flexion and ulnar deviation before traction, which is inappropriate as initial traction is necessary to counteract the shortening and misalignment before specific directional corrections are made.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the management of a Colles' fracture with a POP cast, the correct sequence of reduction is traction, followed by palmar flexion, then ulnar deviation, and finally application of the POP cast.

questions.text: Which one of the following inflammatory markers of muscle biopsy is diagnostic of polymyositis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD8/MHC-I complex

 

  • Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy characterized by muscle weakness. On muscle biopsy, the presence of CD8+ T lymphocytes invading non-necrotic muscle fibers expressing MHC class I (MHC-I) is a hallmark finding.
  • This infiltration of CD8+ T cells that are in direct contact with muscle fibers expressing MHC-I is a specific diagnostic feature of polymyositis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular cell adhesion molecules (VCAM) - While VCAM can be upregulated in areas of inflammation, they are not specific diagnostic markers for polymyositis. VCAMs facilitate the adhesion and passage of leukocytes across the endothelium, a common event in many inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Intracellular adhesion molecules (ICAM) - Similar to VCAMs, ICAMs are involved in the adhesion and trafficking of immune cells during the inflammatory response. Increased expression can be seen in a variety of inflammatory diseases, but they are not specifically diagnostic of polymyositis.

 

Option D. Membrane attack complex (MAC): The MAC is part of the complement system and contributes to the lysis of cells. While the complement system can be activated in various forms of muscle injury, MAC deposition is not a specific feature of polymyositis and is not used for its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the diagnosis of polymyositis, a muscle biopsy showing CD8+ T cells in association with MHC-I on muscle fibers is a critical finding, differentiating it from other inflammatory myopathies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male undergoes elective surgery for gastric cancer. During the surgery, a drain is placed in the surgical site to facilitate drainage of fluid and reduce the risk of postoperative complications. The instrument given in the image is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jackson-Pratt drain

 

  • The given image is of a Jackson-Pratt drain.
  • This is a type of closed drainage system.

 

Option A. Romovac drain: Romovac drains are commonly used after various surgical procedures, including abdominal surgeries, breast surgeries, orthopedic surgeries, and others. They are also utilized in the treatment of abscesses and some types of traumatic injuries. They are a closed drainage system.

 

 

Option C. Minivac drain – (Mini in size): A closed suction drain is placed under your skin during surgery. This drain removes any blood or other fluids that might build up in this area.

 

 

Option D. Corrugated drain: Corrugated drains are intended for open passive drainage, used in situations where wounds must be kept open. They are placed directly into the wounds left to heal by secondary intent. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image above shows Jackson pratt drain often used after abdominal surgery.

questions.text: Which drug is considered the drug of choice for managing ventricular arrhythmias following a myocardial infarction (MI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Xylocaine (Lidocaine)

 

  • Xylocaine (Lidocaine) is traditionally considered the drug of choice for treating ventricular arrhythmias following a myocardial infarction, especially in the acute setting.
  • It works by stabilizing the cardiac membrane and suppressing automaticity in the His-Purkinje system and depolarized myocardium, thereby reducing the occurrence of ectopic beats that can lead to more serious arrhythmias.
  • Lidocaine is effective primarily in acute settings due to its rapid action and minimal effect on heart function outside of the arrhythmic areas.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Quinidine: This drug is a Class IA antiarrhythmic that is used more commonly for atrial arrhythmias and less frequently for ventricular arrhythmias due to its proarrhythmic risks and side effects.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: While Amiodarone is a very effective antiarrhythmic for both ventricular and atrial arrhythmias, its use is generally preferred in chronic management due to its long half-life and the potential for significant side effects, making it less ideal for acute MI settings.

 

Option D. Diphenylhydantoin (Phenytoin): Similar to Lidocaine in some of its effects, Phenytoin is less commonly used for ventricular arrhythmias unless there are specific indications, such as digoxin toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lidocaine (Xylocaine) is traditionally the drug of choice for acute management of ventricular arrhythmias following a myocardial infarction due to its rapid onset, effectiveness, and relatively safe profile for short-term use in this specific context.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension experiences sudden severe chest pain that radiates to the interscapular region. Physical examination reveals bounding pulses with a wide pulse pressure and a diastolic murmur along the left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic dissection

 

  • The patient's presentation of sudden severe chest pain that radiates to the interscapular region, along with bounding pulses and a wide pulse pressure, is highly indicative of an aortic dissection.
  • An aortic dissection occurs when a tear in the inner layer of the aorta allows blood to flow between the layers of the wall of the aorta, which can lead to aortic rupture or decreased perfusion to vital organs.
  • The diastolic murmur heard along the left sternal border could be due to aortic regurgitation, a common complication of ascending aortic dissections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. STEMI (ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction): While STEMI can cause severe chest pain, the pain is typically described as a crushing or squeezing sensation, and it does not typically cause radiating pain to the interscapular region or features such as bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure.

 

Option C. Left Main Stem Disease: This condition could cause significant cardiac symptoms due to severe coronary artery disease; however, it does not typically present with bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, or a diastolic murmur.

 

Option D. Esophageal rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, often following vomiting (Boerhaave syndrome), but it would not typically cause radiating pain to the back, bounding pulses, or a diastolic murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiates to the back, combined with bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, and a diastolic murmur, strongly suggests aortic dissection.
  • This is a medical emergency requiring immediate attention.

choices.text: OC pills can cause failure of anti-epileptic drugs
Anti-epileptic drugs can cause teratogenicity
Anti-epileptic drugs induce metabolism of OC pills
OCPs can reduce clearance of Anti-epileptic drugs and cause toxicity

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with epilepsy is started on anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs). She is also taking oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. Her doctor advises her to use an additional method of contraception. What is the primary reason for this advice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-epileptic drugs induce metabolism of OC pills

 

  • Certain anti-epileptic drugs are known to induce liver enzymes that enhance the metabolism of oral contraceptive pills, leading to decreased effectiveness of the contraceptive.
  • This enzyme-inducing effect can result in lower levels of the hormones provided by the OCPs, thus increasing the risk of unintended pregnancy.
  • Therefore, women on these specific AEDs are often advised to use an alternative or additional form of contraception to ensure effective birth control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OC pills can cause failure of anti-epileptic drugs - This is incorrect; oral contraceptives do not typically affect the efficacy of anti-epileptic drugs.

 

Option B. Anti-epileptic drugs can cause teratogenicity - While true that some AEDs can be teratogenic, this is not the reason for the advice to use additional contraception; it's related to the potential of pregnancy due to reduced efficacy of OCPs.

 

Option D. OCPs can reduce clearance of Anti-epileptic drugs and cause toxicity - This is generally not the case; it's the AEDs that affect the metabolism of the oral contraceptives, not the other way around.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Specifically, the enzyme-inducing properties of some AEDs can lead to increased metabolism of hormones in oral contraceptives, thereby reducing their contraceptive effectiveness and increasing the risk of unintended pregnancy.

questions.text: In the management of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) to alleviate symptoms without causing significant hypotension, which alpha-blocker is preferred?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tamsulosin

 

  • Tamsulosin is specifically targeted at the alpha-1 receptors found predominantly in the prostate and bladder.
  • This selective action makes it effective in reducing the symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia by relaxing the smooth muscles of the bladder neck and prostate without significantly affecting the blood vessels, which helps in avoiding notable decreases in blood pressure.
  • This property makes Tamsulosin a preferred choice for treating BPH, especially in patients where hypotension is a concern.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Terazosin: While Terazosin is effective in treating BPH, it is non-selective and influences alpha-1 receptors in the blood vessels as well, which can lead to hypotension.

 

Option B. Doxazosin: Doxazosin, which like Terazosin, can also cause hypotension due to its non-selective action on alpha receptors.

 

Option C. Phentolamine: This is a non-selective alpha-blocker used mainly for the management of pheochromocytoma and is not used in the treatment of BPH. Its non-selective action can significantly induce hypotension, making it unsuitable for BPH management without affecting blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tamsulosin is the alpha-blocker of choice for managing benign prostatic hyperplasia without causing significant hypotension due to its selectivity for alpha-1 receptors located in the prostate and bladder.

questions.text: Electron dense deposits in the region of hyalinosis and sclerosis, with diffuse loss of foot processes, seen in electron microscopy are features of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

 

  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by segments of the glomeruli within the kidney that exhibit scarring (sclerosis).
  • This condition can be identified under electron microscopy by the presence of electron dense deposits in these sclerotic areas, accompanied by the effacement or loss of the foot processes of podocytes, which are cells that wrap around the capillaries of the glomerulus.
  • These features differentiate FSGS from the other conditions listed, which have their own distinct microscopic findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Characterized by the effacement of the podocyte foot processes but not typically associated with electron dense deposits or sclerotic changes.

 

Option B. Membranous glomerulonephritis: Usually exhibits diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to subepithelial immune deposits, rather than electron dense deposits in the region of sclerosis.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative GN: Characterized by mesangial cell proliferation and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, sometimes with subendothelial and mesangial immune deposits, not specifically electron dense deposits in areas of sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Electron dense deposits and diffuse foot process effacement in regions of hyalinosis and sclerosis on electron microscopy is diagnostic of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis is a podocytopathy characterized by:
    • Focal: only some glomeruli are affected
    • Segmental: only a portion of the glomerular tuft in each affected glomerulus
    • Caused by podocyte injury (primary or secondary)
  • Findings in FSGS by modality:

choices.text: King’s college criteria

questions.text: A 50-year-old male, known case of cirrhosis of the liver presents with an abdominal lump. Imaging reveals solitary 3 x 4 cm nodule with rapid washout of contrast in venous phase. Which clinical criteria would decide suitability for treatment by liver transplant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Milan criteria

 

  • Given scenario is suggestive of cirrhosis complicated by hepatocellular CA (hepatoma).
  • Transplantation for HCC, first described by Mazzaferro in 1996 for patients with tumors ≤5 cm or up to three nodules ≤3 cm, achieved 4-year overall survivals of 75% and recurrence-free survivals of 83%.
  • These inclusion criteria were adopted as the “Milan criteria”, with angioinvasion and extrahepatic involvement as additional exclusion criteria, and are now universally accepted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Child’s score: Severity of chronic liver disease

 

Option B. LIRADS score: Imaging score for diagnosis of liver tumors

 

Option D. King’s college criteria: For liver transplant in acute liver failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patient with cirrhosis and hepatoma, Milan criteria is used to assess suitability for liver transplant.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with flank pain, nausea, and hematuria, suggestive of urinary stone. Urine microscopic examination reveals "dumbbell" shaped crystals. Which type of urinary stone is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium oxalate stones

 

  • These crystals can appear as envelope or dumbbell-shaped under the microscope and are the most common type of kidney stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric acid stones: They typically produce rhomboid or rosette-shaped crystals in urine and are often associated with high purine intake or diseases such as gout.

 

Option C. Struvite stones: This is the correct answer. Struvite stones, composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate, often form in alkaline urine and can create "coffin lid" shaped crystals. They are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria.

 

Option D. Cystine stones: They can be hexagonal in shape under the microscope and are less common, usually associated with a genetic disorder called cystinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identification of "dumb bell " shaped crystals in urinary sediment is indicative of calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl has been experiencing intermittent colicky abdominal pain for a year and recently developed aggressive behavior and paraparesis over the last two days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute intermittent porphyria

 

  • Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a metabolic disorder characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase.
  • This condition leads to the accumulation of porphyrins and their precursors, which can cause a variety of symptoms, including severe abdominal pain, neurological complications (such as paraparesis), and psychiatric symptoms, such as aggressive behavior.
  • The combination of these symptoms, especially with the acute onset of neurological signs, makes AIP a likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion disorder: This is a psychological condition that causes physical neurological symptoms, such as paralysis or numbness, typically following emotional distress. However, it would not explain the biochemical aspect of abdominal pain nor is typically associated with such acute neurological deficits as paraparesis.

 

Option B. Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS): GBS is an acute polyneuropathy, often occurring after an infection, that can cause rapid onset of muscle weakness and paralysis. While GBS could explain the paraparesis, it does not typically include abdominal pain or psychiatric symptoms like aggression.

 

Option D. Abdominal migraine: Primarily seen in children, this condition causes episodes of abdominal pain without gastrointestinal disease. It can be associated with migraine symptoms but does not lead to neurological deficits like paraparesis or behavioral changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of colicky abdominal pain, psychiatric changes, and acute neurological symptoms in a young patient suggests acute intermittent porphyria, a condition requiring biochemical testing and specific management to prevent further complications.

questions.text:
In a clinical trial depicted by an equivalence margin graph, the efficacy of a new drug is compared to an older standard. The trial designers have employed the graph to discern various possible outcomes of the new treatment in comparison to the old. Review the following statements with reference to the graph and identify which are correct:

 

  1. 'A' represents superiority of new treatment.
  2. 'I' represents inferiority of new treatment.
  3. 'E' represents non-inferior treatment.
  4. 'C' is inconclusive.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 only

 

Explanation:

 

  • The equivalence margin graph is designed to evaluate the non-inferiority of a new treatment compared to a standard treatment:
  • The solid vertical line labeled 'Benchmark' indicates the point of no difference (Relative Risk = 1).
  • The dashed vertical line indicates the Delta, which is the smallest margin of inferiority that is considered not clinically significant.
  • If the confidence interval (CI) of a result lies entirely to the right of the Benchmark line, as seen with 'A', it suggests that the new treatment is superior to the standard treatment.
  • If the CI of a result lies entirely to the left of the Delta line, the new treatment would be considered inferior. However, 'I' is not shown on the provided graph; if it were and it were to lie entirely to the left of Delta, it would indicate inferiority.
  • If the CI of a result, like 'E', crosses the Benchmark but does not reach the Delta, it indicates that the new treatment is not inferior to the standard treatment.
  • For a result to be labeled as inconclusive, it would have to not cross the Benchmark (RR = 1) and not lie beyond Delta, which is not the case for 'C' here. However, this result may still be considered inconclusive if the clinical trial's predefined criteria for non-inferiority were not met. The explanation of 'C' as inconclusive is based on the clinical context, which we don't have, but if the CI does not cross the Benchmark and is not to the left of Delta, it is typically inconclusive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In non-inferiority trials using equivalence margin graphs, results to the right of the Benchmark line indicate superiority, results crossing the Benchmark but not reaching Delta suggest non-inferiority, and results beyond Delta indicate inferiority.
  • Results that do not cross the Benchmark and are not beyond Delta are typically inconclusive, but further clinical context is needed for definitive interpretation.

choices.text: Early carcinoma of the colon

questions.text: A 53-year-old man experienced dizziness and observed fresh blood in his stool while defecating. His previous stool tests for colorectal cancer screening were normal. What is the most likely cause of the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angiodysplasia of colon

 

  • Angiodysplasia of the colon is a common vascular lesion of the colon, particularly in the elderly, and can cause acute or chronic bleeding.
  • It often presents as painless bleeding that may be intermittent.
  • The fact that this patient noticed fresh blood and experienced dizziness, which could be related to blood loss, alongside normal colorectal cancer screening results, suggests a non-neoplastic cause like angiodysplasia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sigmoid diverticulitis: This condition generally causes abdominal pain and fever and may lead to bleeding. However, bleeding associated with diverticulitis is less commonly fresh blood and more often mixed with stool, and it typically accompanies signs of inflammation.

 

Option B. Microscopic colitis: This typically presents with watery diarrhea and is not commonly associated with visible blood in the stool, making it less likely in this case.

 

Option D. Early carcinoma of the colon: Early-stage colon cancer usually does not cause significant bleeding evident as fresh blood; it is often occult and not visible. The patient’s normal screening results also make this less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Angiodysplasia of the colon should be considered in older patients presenting with painless fresh blood in the stool, especially when other more common causes like colon cancer have been previously screened out.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with the highest mortality rate once clinical manifestations develop?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rabies

 

  • Rabies is characterized by severe neurological symptoms such as hydrophobia, agitation, and fever following an incubation period that can vary from weeks to months, depending on the location of the virus entry and the amount of virus introduced.
  • Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is almost always fatal, making it the disease with the highest mortality rate once symptoms develop.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H1N1 Influenza: This influenza subtype can cause severe illness, especially in high-risk populations, but has a much lower mortality rate compared to rabies and can be treated effectively with antiviral medications.

 

Option B. Nipah Virus: While the Nipah virus infection does have a high mortality rate (ranging from 40% to 75%), there are survivors after symptom onset. Supportive care and management in a healthcare setting can improve outcomes.

 

Option C. Ebola Virus: Ebola also has a high mortality rate, with rates varying between 25% and 90% depending on the outbreak. However, with supportive care, survival is possible after symptoms develop, unlike rabies which is nearly always fatal without prior vaccination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rabies disease has case fatality rate close to 100%
  • Till date only 3 rabies cases on record have survived

questions.text: Which drug is used in conjunction with phentermine for the management of obesity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Topiramate

 

  • Topiramate, when used in combination with phentermine, has been approved for the management of obesity.
  • This combination, marketed under the name Qsymia, utilizes the appetite-suppressing effects of phentermine and the weight reduction properties of topiramate to effectively manage weight in obese patients.
  • The combination is considered because it targets multiple pathways related to appetite and satiety.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Orlistat: Orlistat works by inhibiting fat absorption in the intestine and is used alone for weight management, not typically in combination with phentermine.

 

Option B. Lorcaserin: This drug was used to suppress appetite by activating serotonin receptors but was withdrawn from the market in 2020 due to an increased risk of cancer.

 

Option C. Sibutramine: Sibutramine was another appetite suppressant but was removed from many markets due to cardiovascular safety concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Students should remember that topiramate, in combination with phentermine, is approved for the management of obesity, targeting multiple mechanisms affecting appetite and satiety.
  • This combination offers an effective treatment option for weight management in obese patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient develops cardiogenic shock following acute myocardial infarction. His urine output decreases in the next few days. He has increased serum urea and creatinine; urine analysis reveals no glucose or protein but numerous hyaline casts are present. After a few days, he develops polyuria and serum creatinine level falls. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute Tubular Necrosis

 

  • The clinical course described in the question suggests Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN), particularly in the context of cardiogenic shock following a myocardial infarction.
  • ATN is commonly seen as a result of ischemia or toxin exposure, which leads to damage of the tubular cells in the kidneys.
  • The presence of hyaline casts (which are typically found in conditions of low urine flow or dehydration) and the pattern of initial oliguria (decreased urine output), followed by a phase of polyuria as the renal tubules begin to recover and are able to excrete but not concentrate urine, are characteristic of ATN.
  • The increase in serum creatinine and urea indicates a decrease in renal function, which is consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atheroembolic disease: Typically presents with renal impairment following procedures that can dislodge atherosclerotic plaques, such as angiography, but is not directly related to the pattern of urine output and renal recovery described.

 

Option C. Acute Interstitial Nephritis: This condition, often drug-induced, would more likely present with features of allergic reaction and show white blood cells or eosinophils in the urine, not just hyaline casts.

 

Option D. Pigment Nephropathy: Associated with the breakdown of muscle tissue leading to the release of myoglobin (as in rhabdomyolysis), which is not indicated in this case since the urine analysis did not show myoglobinuria (characterized by dark, tea-colored urine).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with cardiogenic shock following myocardial infarction, a diagnosis of acute tubular necrosis is likely when the clinical course includes initial oliguria with worsening renal function followed by a polyuric phase, along with the presence of hyaline casts in urine analysis. This reflects the typical recovery phase of ATN.

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks’ gestation reports sudden headache and blurred vision. She is found to have a blood pressure of 170/110 mm Hg, significant proteinuria (+++), and retinal hemorrhages on fundus examination. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate anticonvulsive therapy

 

  • This patient exhibits severe preeclampsia with neurological symptoms, which puts her at high risk for eclampsia.
  • Immediate administration of anticonvulsive therapy, typically with magnesium sulfate, is critical to prevent the progression to eclampsia, characterized by seizures that can be life-threatening to both mother and fetus.
  • This intervention is a priority even before considering delivery methods, as it directly addresses the acute risk of seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative treatment: This is inappropriate due to the acute severity and high risks associated with her symptoms.

 

Option C. Induce labor: While delivery is the definitive treatment for preeclampsia, the immediate risk of seizures must be addressed first with anticonvulsants.

 

Option D. Proceed with cesarean delivery: Although delivery is necessary, the initial step in the presence of neurological symptoms is to stabilize the patient with anticonvulsants to prevent seizures. Delivery planning can follow once the patient is stabilized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of severe preeclampsia with neurological symptoms, the initial management should prioritize the prevention of eclampsia through the administration of anticonvulsants.

questions.text: A patient presents with oral lesions as shown in the image, which demonstrate a white, cottage cheese-like appearance. The culture of the lesion displays branching at narrowed ends. Given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C. albicans

 

Option B. C. albicans: Candida albicans is a yeast that causes oral thrush, presenting with white, curd-like plaques on the mucous membranes that can be scraped off. It can form both yeast cells and pseudohyphae, which can appear as branching structures in cultures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C. diphtheriae: This bacterium causes diphtheria, typically presenting with a gray pseudomembrane in the throat rather than the white plaques seen in the image. It would not display yeast-like branching in culture since it's a bacterium, not a fungus.

 

Option C. CMV: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection can cause ulcerations in the mouth, especially in immunocompromised patients, but does not cause the white plaque-like lesions seen with Candida infections. Additionally, CMV does not exhibit branching in cultures, as it is a virus.

 

Option D. HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) causes oral herpes, presenting as vesicles or ulcerative lesions, not white plaques. HSV would not show branching in culture, as it is also a virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush) presents as white, adherent, painless patches in the mouth.
  • Candida on culture smear appears gram-positive budding yeast cells with long pseudohyphae.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the clinic with weakness in the thumb and difficulty gripping objects. On examination, the patient exhibits a loss of opposition of the thumb, as well as atrophy of the thenar eminence. Which of the following muscles is primarily supplied by the median nerve and is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flexor Pollicis Brevis

 

  • In this case thumb/thenar muscles are involved which are supplied by median nerve (except Grave yard of ulnar nerve i.e.- adductor pollicis which is supplied by ulnar nerve.)
  • Among given options only Flexor pollicis brevis is thenar muscle hence it is the answer.
  • 4 Thenar Muscles shown in image:

 

 

  • 4 Hypothenar Muscles shown in image :

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmaris brevis is innervated by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. All dorsal interossei are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flexor pollicis brevis, Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, first and second lumbricals in the hand are innervated by the median nerve.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with a history of similar episodes since childhood and a family history of comparable symptoms presents with acute severe dyspnea, laryngeal stridor, and airway obstruction but no fever, urticaria, or recurrent infections. Normal lab values for WBC, hematocrit, and platelets are noted. Which deficiency is likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C1 inhibitor

 

  • The clinical presentation is indicative of hereditary angioedema, characterized by recurrent episodes of severe, localized edema without urticaria.
  • This is typically due to a deficiency of the C1 inhibitor, which controls the activation of the complement system and the kinin pathway.
  • Without adequate C1 inhibitor function, there is unregulated production of bradykinin, leading to increased vascular permeability and episodes of edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. β2-Microglobulin: This is associated with the immune response and is not directly related to the symptoms described, which are characteristic of hereditary angioedema.

 

Option C. C3: Deficiencies in C3 can lead to recurrent infections due to its role in opsonization and phagocytosis, which are not reported in the patient's history.

 

Option D. 5-Hydroxytryptamine: Also known as serotonin, a deficiency in this neurotransmitter does not lead to the symptoms described, which are more consistent with a C1 inhibitor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deficiency in C1 inhibitor leads to hereditary angioedema, which presents with recurrent, non-urticarial edema and is not associated with an allergic reaction or anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple tense blisters over the body associated with pruritus. On histopathology subepidermal split and eosinophils are visible. Which is the most likely antigen causative for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BPAG 180

 

  • The correct answer is A, BPAG 180. The clinical presentation of tense blisters associated with pruritus and the histopathological finding of subepidermal split and eosinophils suggests a diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid.
  • Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune subepidermal blistering disorder characterized by autoantibodies directed against BPAG1 (BPAG 230) and BPAG2 (BPAG 180).
  • Among these, BPAG 180 (also known as BP180 or collagen XVII) is particularly associated with the formation of tense blisters and eosinophilic involvement, as seen in this case.
  • BPAG 180 serves as a transmembrane protein that is crucial in the adhesion of the epidermis to the dermis, and antibodies against it lead to blister formation beneath the epidermal layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BPAG 230: BPAG 230, also known as BP230, is another target antigen in bullous pemphigoid. However, it is less likely to be involved when compared to BPAG 180.

 

Option C. Collagen 7: This is the main target antigen in epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, not typically associated with neutrophil-rich inflammatory infiltrates but rather with deeper, often more scarring blisters.

 

Option D. Desmoglein 3: Desmoglein 3 is a target antigen in pemphigus vulgaris, a condition characterized by suprabasal acantholysis and flaccid blisters, not tense blisters. Pemphigus vulgaris often presents with mucosal involvement and does not commonly show neutrophil predominance on histopathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BPAG 180 > BPAG 230 is the target antigen associated with bullous pemphigoid, which presents with tense blisters and can involve eosinophilic infiltration on histopathology.

questions.text: A pediatrician discusses newborn screening tests with a group of expectant parents at a community health seminar. He describes a test as shown in the image below. What is the name of this newborn screening test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Guthrie test

 

  • Originally developed to screen for phenylketonuria, the Guthrie test now encompasses a broader array of metabolic and genetic disorders.
  • It involves pricking the heel of a newborn to collect blood on a Guthrie card.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hirschberg test: This is a clinical test used to assess ocular alignment and detect strabismus, not a screening test for metabolic disorders.

 

Option C. Foot prick test: While technically describing the method used in the Guthrie test, "Foot prick test" is not the specific name recognized for the newborn screening test.

 

Option D. Heel print test: This option might confuse the heel prick method with a test name, but it does not accurately describe the screening test known as the Guthrie test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Guthrie test is a critical component of newborn screening, allowing early detection and intervention for various metabolic and genetic disorders.
  • Early identification of these conditions can significantly improve the long-term health and development of affected children through timely management and treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a 6 x 4 cm right breast lump in the upper medial quadrant. Lump is fixed to pectoralis major. Examination reveals no axillary nodes but right-sided supraclavicular node. Her TNM stage is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3N3cM0

 

  • 6 cm tumor implies T3. Fixity to P. Major doesn’t affect T stage
  • Presence of ipsilateral supraclavicular nodal metastasis is seen- N3c.
  • Any contra-lateral nodal involvement is M1 disease. In this case, its M0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 6 cm tumor with ipsilateral supraclavicular LN metastasis is T3N3cM0.

choices.text: Thermodynamically possible only when gluconeogenesis occurs
Needs Protein Kinase for its activation
Enzyme is present in SER; Glucose 6-phosphate needs to be transported into SER
Steric inhibition of Phosphatase by albumin

questions.text: Why is Glucose 6 Phosphate in the cytoplasm of hepatocyte not acted upon by Glucose 6 Phosphatase as soon as it is formed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enzyme is present in SER, Glucose 6-phosphate needs to be transported into SER.

 

  • Glucose 6-phosphatase, which is involved in the final step of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), specifically the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) of hepatocytes.
  • For glucose 6-phosphate to be dephosphorylated into free glucose, which can then be released into the bloodstream, it must be transported into the SER.
  • This step is a regulatory point ensuring that glucose is not prematurely released and that it is only released when needed, such as between meals or during fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thermodynamically possible only when gluconeogenesis occurs: While gluconeogenesis includes the action of glucose 6-phosphatase, the location of the enzyme is the primary reason it does not immediately act on glucose 6-phosphate in the cytoplasm.

 

Option B. Needs Protein Kinase for its activation: Glucose 6-phosphatase activity is not regulated by protein kinase but rather by its location and substrate availability.

 

Option D. Steric inhibition of Phosphatase by albumin: There is no known regulatory mechanism involving the steric inhibition of glucose 6-phosphatase by albumin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme localized in the SER, and for it to act on glucose 6-phosphate, the substrate must first be transported into the SER.
  • This compartmentalization plays an essential role in regulating endogenous glucose production and maintaining blood glucose levels.

choices.text: Can incorporate 2 atoms of O2 in a substance
Can incorporate 1 atom of O2 in a substance
Important in hydroxylation of steroids

questions.text: All are true about oxygenases, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catalyse carboxylation of drugs

 

  • Oxygenases are enzymes that incorporate oxygen into the substrates they act upon. There are two main types of oxygenases: monooxygenases (or mixed-function oxidases) and dioxygenases.
  • Monooxygenases incorporate one atom of the molecular oxygen into the substrate (as in hydroxylation reactions), while the other oxygen atom is reduced to water.
  • Dioxygenases incorporate both atoms of molecular oxygen into the substrate.
  • The activity of oxygenases is indeed important in the hydroxylation of steroids and in incorporating oxygen into various substances.
  • However, they are not typically involved in carboxylation reactions, which add a carboxyl group (COOH) to a substrate. Carboxylation reactions are typically catalyzed by carboxylases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Can incorporate 2 atoms of O2 in a substance: This is true for dioxygenases, a type of oxygenase that incorporates both atoms of oxygen into its substrates.

 

Option B. Can incorporate 1 atom of O2 in a substance: This is true for monooxygenases, which incorporate one atom of oxygen into the substrate and reduce the other to water.

 

Option C. Important in hydroxylation of steroids: This is true; hydroxylation, a type of reaction catalyzed by monooxygenases, is crucial in steroid metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While oxygenases are enzymes that incorporate oxygen into substrates and are vital for hydroxylation reactions, such as those occurring in steroid metabolism, they do not catalyze carboxylation reactions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a known case of fibroid uterus consults for potential surgical options. She experiences symptoms that may warrant surgical intervention. Which of the following is not a typical indication for myomectomy in cases of uterine fibroids?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Red degeneration

 

  • Red degeneration refers to acute necrosis of fibroid tissue, which can cause severe pain and is typically managed conservatively with pain relief and observation rather than surgery.
  • Red degeneration usually occurs during pregnancy or under hormonal influence and does not typically require myomectomy unless symptoms persist or worsen significantly despite medical management.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Associated infertility: Fibroids that distort the uterine cavity can interfere with implantation or lead to infertility, making myomectomy a reasonable treatment to potentially enhance fertility.


Option B. Recurrent pregnancy loss: Fibroids, particularly submucosal types, can be a cause of recurrent miscarriages. Removal via myomectomy may improve pregnancy outcomes.


Option C. Pressure symptoms: Large fibroids can cause pressure symptoms on adjacent pelvic organs such as the bladder or rectum. Myomectomy is indicated to relieve these symptoms if they significantly impact the patient's quality of life.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Myomectomy is indicated for managing symptoms or reproductive issues associated with fibroids, red degeneration of fibroids is generally managed conservatively, and surgery is not the first-line treatment unless there are exceptional circumstances.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a history of nephrotic syndrome presents to the emergency department with acute onset of breathlessness. On examination her pulse rate is 121/min, blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation at 86%. Bedside echocardiography shows right ventricular dysfunction. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alteplase

 

  • The clinical presentation of a patient with acute onset of breathlessness, tachycardia, hypotension, hypoxia, and echocardiographic evidence of right ventricular dysfunction strongly suggests a massive pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • Alteplase, a thrombolytic agent, is indicated in the management of massive PE associated with hemodynamic instability, as it can rapidly dissolve the thrombus, improving the patient's cardiac function and oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: While enoxaparin is an anticoagulant used to treat and prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, it is not sufficient in the acute management of a massive PE with hemodynamic instability where rapid thrombolysis is needed.

 

Option C. IVC filter: An inferior vena cava (IVC) filter could be considered in situations where anticoagulation is contraindicated or has failed, but it is not the first-line treatment in acute management of massive PE with hemodynamic instability.

 

Option D. Thrombectomy: Surgical thrombectomy or catheter-directed thrombectomy could be considered if thrombolytic therapy is contraindicated or if the patient does not respond to thrombolytics, but thrombolytics are usually tried first due to their quicker implementation and broad availability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with nephrotic syndrome presenting with signs of a massive pulmonary embolism and right ventricular dysfunction, the use of a thrombolytic agent like alteplase is the most appropriate next step to rapidly address the life-threatening thrombus and stabilize the patient's condition.

choices.text: Signature of the doctor
Functioning pulse oximeter
Sterility of instruments

questions.text: In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, which of the following is not a component?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Signature of the doctor

 

  • In a preoperative patient surgical safety checklist, a doctor's signature is not needed.
  • The signature of the doctor, is not typically a component of the surgical safety checklist. Instead, the checklist focuses on verifying critical safety elements like patient consent, equipment functionality, and instrument sterility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Consent: Ensuring that informed consent has been obtained from the patient is a crucial component of preoperative safety checklists. It confirms that the patient has been informed about the procedure, risks, and alternatives and has given their consent for the surgery.

 

Option C. Functioning pulse oximeter: Checking the functioning of medical equipment like a pulse oximeter is an important step in preoperative safety. It ensures that necessary monitoring devices are in working order to monitor the patient's vital signs during surgery.

 

Option D. Sterility of instruments: Verifying the sterility of surgical instruments is essential to prevent infections during surgery. It ensures that all instruments that will come into contact with the patient are properly sterilized and safe for use.

 

Educational objective:

choices.text: Search for literature is compulsory using explicit search strategy
Critical appraisal is always criterion based

questions.text: A medical researcher is planning to conduct a systematic review and seeks advice regarding the essential features of systematic reviews. Which of the following is NOT necessarily a feature of systematic reviews?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meta-analysis always performed

 

  • Meta-analysis is a statistical technique used to combine the results of multiple studies that address a set of related research hypotheses. However, it is not always a component of systematic reviews.
  • While many systematic reviews include a meta-analysis, it is possible to conduct a systematic review that synthesizes qualitative data or where quantitative synthesis (meta-analysis) is not appropriate due to the heterogeneity of studies or lack of sufficient data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Search for literature is compulsory using explicit search strategy: This is a core feature of systematic reviews. A systematic review requires a thorough, reproducible search of the literature using explicit and systematic methods to collect secondary data and analyze published research.

 

Option C. Critical appraisal is always criterion based: Systematic reviews typically include a critical appraisal step, where studies are evaluated based on pre-defined criteria to assess their quality. This ensures that conclusions are based on high-quality evidence.

 

Option D. Research question always focused: Systematic reviews are characterized by a highly focused research question, which defines the scope and direction of the review. This specificity is crucial to effectively search for and analyze relevant literature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis can (and should) be embedded in a systematic review, but this is not always done
  • A single systematic review can contain multiple metaanalyses
  • SYSTEMATIC REVIEW: A document related after comprehensively reviewing and combining all the information from both published and unpublished studies (focusing on a particular clinical or health related topic/question) and then summarizing the findings

questions.text: Punnet’s square is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Finding genotype of offspring

 

  • Punnett’s square is primarily used in genetics to predict the possible genotypes of offspring from a cross of two parents.
  • Each parent’s allele combinations for a particular gene are placed on the top and side of the square, and the square is filled to show all possible allele combinations in the offspring.
  • This tool is pivotal in visualizing how alleles can combine, allowing predictions about genetic outcomes such as dominant or recessive trait manifestation.
  • Given that the researcher is aiming to forecast the distribution of traits from parental genotypes, the use of Punnett’s square is most aptly described as "Finding genotype of offspring."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Random Sampling: This method is used in statistics to ensure that every individual in a population has an equal chance of being selected. It’s unrelated to genetic prediction methods such as the Punnett’s square, which is a deterministic tool, not a sampling method.

 

Option B. Statistical Analysis: Though genetic studies often involve statistical analyses to interpret data, Punnett’s square itself is a predictive tool used prior to such analyses to determine expected genetic outcomes, not to analyze statistical data post hoc.

 

Option D. Test of Significance: This refers to statistical tests used to determine if the results observed in data are due to random chance or a true effect. This is not the function of a Punnett’s square, which is used for prediction rather than hypothesis testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PUNNETT SQUARE

 

  • Is a diagram that is used to predict the result of a cross/breeding experiment
  • Is representing summary of every possible combination of each maternal allele with paternal allele for each gene studied in square
  • Is used by biologists ‘to determine the probability of an offspring having a particular genotype’
  • Can be used for both monohybrid and dihybrid cross
  • Are standard tools for genetic counsellors

 

• Typical example of a Punnett square:

questions.text: When constructing a sanitary well, it is essential to consider the minimum depth of the lining to ensure water safety and prevent contamination. What is the minimum depth for the lining of a sanitary well?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20 feet

 

  • Sanitary well linings are typically designed to prevent surface contaminants from entering the water supply.
  • The minimum depth of 20 feet is considered standard to ensure that there is sufficient barrier between the surface and the water source.
  • This depth helps in managing the potential risk of contamination from near-surface sources, including biological and chemical runoff.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sanitary Well Guidelines –

 

  • Location: <100 m radial distance; >15 m (50 feet) from source of contamination
  • Lining: >6 m (20 feet) depth; >60-90 cm (2-3 feet) above ground level
  • Parapet wall: >70-75 cms above ground
  • Platform: >1 m (3 feet) in all directions
  • Other guidelines: Pucca drain to a soakage pit/public drain beyond cone of filtration; cement concrete cover; robust hand pump to withdraw water

choices.text: Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium
Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium

questions.text: What causes the appearance of the torus aorticus in the heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium

 

  • Torus aorticus is produced by bulging of the right posterior aortic sinus.
  • It is seen in the anterosuperior part of the interatrial septum in the right atrium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrium Bulging into Aorta: Normally, there is no structural feature in which an atrium bulges into the aorta. The atria and the aorta are separate chambers with distinct functions.

 

Option B. Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium: Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium are the dilations at the root of the aorta, just above the aortic valve. While these sinuses are close to the left atrium, they do not bulge into it. The structure of the heart prevents such an occurrence under normal conditions, and such a bulging would likely indicate a pathological condition.

 

Option D. Aortic Wall Tear: Aortic Wall Tear, also known as an aortic dissection, where the inner layer of the aorta tears, causing blood to flow between the layers of the wall of the aorta. This condition does not lead to the formation of the torus aorticus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium:  

 

  • The torus aorticus is caused by the bulging of the right posterior aortic sinus into the right atrium.
  • The aortic sinus, one of the three aortic sinuses, is located near the right atrium. The bulging of this sinus into the right atrium can create a noticeable impression, known as the torus aorticus, on the wall of the right atrium.

choices.text: The inflammatory process is confined to the mucosa and submucosa.
The inflammatory reaction is likely to be continuous.
Superficial as opposed to linear ulcerations can be expected.
Non-caseating granulomas can be expected in up to 50% of patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient who presents with diarrhea and abdominal discomfort is found at colonoscopy to have colitis confined to the transverse and descending colon with multiple ulcers. Fecal calprotectin is positive. A biopsy is performed. Which of the following is a finding consistent with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-caseating granulomas can be expected in up to 50% of patients.

 

  • The limited colonic involvement with predominant diarrhoea is suggestive of Crohn’s disease.
  • In Ulcerative colitis, disease begins in rectum, which is not seen here.
  • Histology typically demonstrates discontinuous segments of disease or ‘skip lesions’, involvement of the terminal ileum and the presence of granulomas (>50%) with a tendency for more marked inflammation in the proximal colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The inflammatory process is confined to the mucosa and submucosa: The transmural inflammation may be patchy (rather than diffuse) and crypt distortion is commonly seen.

 

Option B. The inflammatory reaction is likely to be continuous and Option C. Superficial as opposed to linear ulcerations can be expected: Crohn’s disease is characterized by discontinuous transmural inflammation of the bowel, of any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, but most commonly the ileocaecal region, colon, and anus. There is often a degree of rectal sparing when the colon is involved. Deep linear ulcers are seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crohn’s is characterised by transmural inflammation, skip lesions, deep ulcers and noncaseating granulomas.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in a patient with tuberous sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vigabatrin

 

  • Vigabatrin is the drug of choice for infantile spasms, particularly in patients with tuberous sclerosis.
  • This medication works by increasing the levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter.
  • Vigabatrin's effectiveness in this context is particularly noted due to its specific efficacy in cases associated with tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder that often causes seizures including infantile spasms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tiagabine: While Tiagabine also acts by modulating GABA, it is not the first-line treatment for infantile spasms and has not shown the same level of efficacy as Vigabatrin in this particular setting.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug used for various types of seizures, but it is not the primary choice for infantile spasms.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Known for a broad spectrum of action against seizures, Levetiracetam is not specifically preferred for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis compared to Vigabatrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vigabatrin is the preferred treatment for infantile spasms in patients with tuberous sclerosis due to its specific action of increasing GABA in the brain, effectively managing seizures in this particular context.

choices.text: 1, 3, 5
1, 2, 3
1, 2, 5
1, 5

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are associated with empty nose syndrome?

 

  1. Widely patent nasal cavity
  2. Previous history of nasal surgery with resection of turbinates
  3. Chronic nasal discharge
  4. Relieved by surgical resection of turbinates
  5. Foul smell from the nose
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 5

 

Explanation:

 

  • Option 1. Widely patent nasal cavity (True): A widely patent nasal cavity is indeed associated with empty nose syndrome (ENS). ENS is characterized by a range of nasal symptoms despite having widely clear nasal passages, including obstruction, dryness, and crusting.
  • Option 2. Previous history of nasal surgery with resection of turbinates (True): Previous history of nasal surgery with resection of turbinates is a significant risk factor for ENS. Turbinectomy or other surgical procedures that interfere with turbinates can lead to the development of ENS.
  • Option 3. Chronic nasal discharge (False): Chronic nasal discharge is not a typical feature of empty nose syndrome (ENS). Instead, patients with ENS often complain of nasal dryness and crusting.
  • Option 4. Relieved by surgical resection of turbinates (False): ENS is not relieved by surgical resection of turbinates. In fact, previous turbinectomy may be the cause of ENS, as mentioned earlier.
  • Option 5. Foul smell from the nose (True): Foul smell from the nose is a characteristic symptom of ENS. Patients with ENS may experience a foul odour emanating from their nose due to marked anosmia (loss of sense of smell) associated with the condition.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Empty nose syndrome (ENS) is a condition characterized by a range of nasal symptoms, including obstruction, dryness, and crusting, despite having widely clear nasal passages. Risk factors for ENS include previous nasal surgery with resection of turbinates.
  • Symptoms of ENS may include foul smell from the nose, nasal dryness, and marked anosmia.
  • Treatment options include medical management and surgical procedures aimed at addressing the symptoms and improving nasal function.

questions.text: In the treatment of diabetes insipidus, which diuretic demonstrates a paradoxical antidiuretic effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiazide

 

  • Thiazide diuretics show a paradoxical antidiuretic activity in patients with diabetes insipidus.
  • While thiazides are typically used to increase urine output by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, in diabetes insipidus, they reduce urine volume.
  • This effect is believed to be due to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and an increase in sodium and water reabsorption in more proximal segments of the nephron.
  • This helps reduce polyuria, one of the key symptoms of diabetes insipidus.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Triamterene: This potassium-sparing diuretic affects the distal renal tubules but does not typically exhibit a paradoxical antidiuretic effect in diabetes insipidus.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Also a potassium-sparing diuretic, Spironolactone acts primarily as an aldosterone antagonist and does not demonstrate the paradoxical antidiuretic effect seen with thiazide diuretics in diabetes insipidus.

 

Option C. Furosemide: A loop diuretic that increases urine output by acting on the loop of Henle, Furosemide does not exhibit a paradoxical antidiuretic effect in diabetes insipidus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In diabetes insipidus, thiazide diuretics can paradoxically reduce urine output, unlike their usual diuretic action, by reducing glomerular filtration and enhancing proximal tubular reabsorption of sodium and water.
  • This counterintuitive use of thiazides is a crucial clinical approach to managing diabetes insipidus.

choices.text: Halo nevus phenomenon
Reverse Koebner phenomenon

questions.text: Parents of a 2-year-old child present to the dermatology clinic with a skin lesion on the arm. Upon examination, the lesion is identified as a melanocytic nevus with a noticeable eczematous halo around it. The parents report that the halo developed a few weeks ago, and the child has been scratching the lesion since the appearance of halo. Which of the following best describes the observed dermatological phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meyerson phenomenon

 

  • This is characterized by an eczematous halo surrounding a melanocytic nevus.
  • Patients may present with itching and erythema around a pre-existing mole, as seen in the image provided.
  • This phenomenon is not associated with malignancy, and the management usually involves topical treatments for the eczema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Halo nevus phenomenon: This typically refers to a melanocytic nevus surrounded by a depigmented halo, often considered to be an immune response where the body's immune system attacks the pigment cells in the mole.

 

 

It is not characterized by eczematous changes.

 

Option B. The Reverse Koebner phenomenon: This refers to the clearing and healing of psoriatic lesions following injury. This is not consistent with the patient's presentation, as It is not characterized by eczematous changes.

 

Option C. Sutton's phenomenon: This is also known as halo nevus, is similar to option A and describes a melanocytic nevus with a surrounding area of depigmentation, not an eczematous ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meyerson phenomenon, which refers to the eczematous halo surrounding a pre-existing skin lesion, often a nevus, with associated pruritus and erythema.
  • This phenomenon is distinct from the depigmented halo seen in a halo nevus.

choices.text: Granulocyte – macrophage colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, has been experiencing increasing dyspnea and a cough over the past week. In the last two days, she has had a productive cough with copious sputum. Upon examination, although afebrile, she exhibits extensive dullness to percussion across all lung fields. Her chest X-ray shows bilateral diffuse opacification. Electron microscopy of the lung biopsy reveals many lamellar bodies. The antibodies present are directed against which substance in the pathogenesis of the condition described?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granulocyte – macrophage colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF)

 

  • The clinical features and the presence of many lamellar bodies on the lung biopsy are indicative of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).
  • In PAP, there is an accumulation of surfactant due to impaired clearance by alveolar macrophages.
  • The antibody that is most commonly associated with PAP targets GM-CSF, which is critical for the maturation and function of alveolar macrophages.
  • The presence of anti-GM-CSF antibodies disrupts the normal degradation of surfactant, leading to the accumulation seen in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CFTR: This gene is related to cystic fibrosis, which is a different pathophysiological process involving mucus production and not the accumulation of surfactant or the presence of lamellar bodies.

 

Option C. DNA topoisomerase 1: This enzyme is associated with systemic sclerosis and is not directly related to the pathogenesis of PAP.

 

Option D. Glomerular basement membrane: Antibodies to the glomerular basement membrane are associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which involves both the renal and pulmonary systems but does not cause the accumulation of surfactant and lamellar bodies typical of PAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When encountering a lung biopsy with many lamellar bodies and a clinical picture of progressive dyspnea and cough, one should think of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, which is often associated with the presence of anti-GM-CSF antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following structure, frequently discussed in liver disease context, is actually not a derivative of the septum transversum?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligamentum Teres

 

  • Ligamentum teres hepatis is obliterated left umbilical vein.

 

 

  • The septum transversum is an important embryological structure that contributes to the formation of several components of the liver and its associated ligaments.
  • The falciform ligament and coronary ligament are derivatives of the septum transversum.
  • The lesser omentum, however, is not derived from the septum transversum but rather from the ventral mesogastrium.
  • This structure is clinically significant as it connects the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Falciform Ligament: The falciform ligament is a derivative of the septum transversum. It is a ligament that attaches the liver to the anterior abdominal wall and diaphragm. The falciform ligament is a remnant of the ventral mesentery and is associated with the development of the liver, which is intimately related to the septum transversum.

 

Option C. Coronary Ligament: The coronary ligament of the liver is a derivative of the septum transversum. It helps to attach the liver to the diaphragm and is an important structure in the peritoneal reflections around the liver.

 

Option D. Lesser Omentum: The lesser omentum, which extends from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum, is partially derived from the septum transversum. It is a remnant of the ventral mesentery and plays a role in forming the anterior boundary of the omental bursa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ligamentum teres, also known as the round ligament of the liver, is not a direct derivative of the septum transversum.
  • It is actually a remnant of the umbilical vein, which carried oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus during embryonic development.
  • After birth, the umbilical vein obliterates and becomes the ligamentum teres.

questions.text: Identify the primary utility of the tube shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Variceal bleed.

 

  • The given image shows Sengstaken Blakemore tube, used for balloon tamponade in variceal bleed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bladder wash and Option C. Bleeding after TURP: For bladder wash and bleeding after TUR-P, Foleys catheter is used.

 

Option D. Epistaxis: For epistaxis, nasal packing is done. A small sized Foley’s may be used for tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The picture shows a sengstaken blakemore tube used for control of bleeding during esophageal variceal bleeding.

choices.text: Bell and pad based classical conditioning
Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has been bed-wetting twice a week for the past year, and organic causes have been ruled out. What is the most appropriate treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bell and pad based classical conditioning

 

  • Bell and pad based classical conditioning is a well-established and effective behavioral treatment for nocturnal enuresis (bed-wetting).
  • This method uses a moisture-sensitive device that triggers an alarm when wetting begins, thereby conditioning the child to wake up and interrupt micturition.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Typically used to address underlying emotional issues, it is less direct and often not the first-line treatment for bed-wetting.

 

Option B. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: This is an option but usually considered when behavioral treatments fail because of potential side effects.

 

Option D. Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime: Useful for daytime urinary incontinence but less effective for nocturnal enuresis, which often involves different mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Bell and pad based classical conditioning is an effective first-line behavioral treatment for nocturnal enuresis in children, aiming to condition the child to wake up and use the toilet in response to bladder fullness.

questions.text: Structure that divides liver anatomically based on the Couinaud classification system is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Portal vein

 

  • In the Couinaud classification system, the liver is divided into segments based on the distribution of the portal vein branches.
  • Each segment is an area of the liver tissue that is anatomically defined by its own vascular inflow, outflow, and biliary drainage.
  • This system is widely used to describe liver anatomy and plan liver surgeries, such as resections, by dividing the liver into eight functionally independent segments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic artery: While the hepatic artery does supply blood to the liver, it does not serve as the primary anatomical divider in the Couinaud classification system.

 

Option C. Bile duct: The biliary system, including the bile ducts, is important for the drainage of bile from the liver segments, but it is not the primary structure used to divide the liver anatomically in this system.

 

Option D. Cystic duct: The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct and has no role in the anatomical division of the liver according to the Couinaud classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Couinaud classification system uses the distribution of the portal vein branches to anatomically divide the liver into segments, which is essential for understanding liver anatomy, especially in the context of surgical planning and hepatic resections.

choices.text: Administration of a single dose of ampicillin or a first-generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery
Skin closure with staples rather than with suture

questions.text: In an effort to minimize the risk of puerperal infection after cesarean delivery, various techniques and practices are evaluated. Which of the following has a proven benefit in decreasing the incidence of puerperal infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administration of a single dose of ampicillin or a first-generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery

 

  • The administration of prophylactic antibiotics, such as ampicillin or first-generation cephalosporins, prior to skin incision during cesarean delivery has been consistently shown to reduce the incidence of postoperative infections, including puerperal infections.
  • This practice is supported by extensive clinical research and is recommended by various obstetrical guidelines globally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-closure of peritoneum: While this may reduce operating time and postoperative pain, it has not been conclusively shown to reduce puerperal infection rates.


Option B. Single layer uterine closure: This technique may affect the integrity of the uterine scar and is debated in terms of infection reduction; the evidence is not definitive regarding its impact on puerperal infection rates.


Option D. Skin closure with staples rather than with suture: Studies have shown mixed results; some suggest that staples may increase the risk of wound infection compared to sutures, though this is still subject to ongoing debate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prophylactic administration of antibiotics before cesarean delivery is a proven and recommended practice to significantly reduce the risk of puerperal infection, enhancing both maternal safety and postoperative recovery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary focus of emporiatrics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Health of travellers

 

  • Emporiatrics is specifically the study of medical considerations and preventive care for international travellers.
