  • This field includes evaluating health risks associated with travel, advising on vaccinations, and preventive measures to ensure traveller health and safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occupational disease: This involves diseases related to the specific environments and risks associated with particular occupations, not travel.

 

Option B. Air pollution: While important in environmental health, air pollution is not the central focus of emporiatrics.

 

Option C. Environmental factors: Though these are considered in emporiatrics, the term specifically pertains to health issues facing travellers, not general environmental health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Travel medicine or ‘Emporiatrics’ is the branch of medicine that deals with the prevention and management of health problems of international travellers.

questions.text: Which of the following would distinguish hydrocephalus due to aqueductal stenosis when compared to that due to Dandy-Walker malformation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior fossa volume

 

  • Dandy-Walker malformation is characterized by an enlarged posterior fossa due to cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle and agenesis or hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis.
  • In contrast, aqueductal stenosis would not typically result in an enlarged posterior fossa, but rather isolated enlargement of the lateral and third ventricles due to obstruction at the level of the cerebral aqueduct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Third ventricle size: While enlargement of the third ventricle can occur in both conditions, it is not specific enough to differentiate between them.

 

Option C. Lateral ventricular size: Similarly, both conditions can cause enlargement of the lateral ventricles due to the buildup of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

 

Option D. Head circumference: An increased head circumference can be a result of any type of hydrocephalus and is not distinctive between aqueductal stenosis and Dandy-Walker malformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key differentiating feature of Dandy-Walker malformation in the context of hydrocephalus is the enlarged posterior fossa, which is not a characteristic finding in hydrocephalus due to aqueductal stenosis.

choices.text: The patient is classified as having stage IIIb endometrial cancer.
No additional treatment is necessary since lymphadenectomy has been performed.
Lymphadenectomy in endometrial cancer is essential for determining the stage and planning subsequent treatment.
Adjuvant vaginal brachytherapy will be required as part of her treatment plan.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman has undergone a hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and extensive lymph node dissection for endometrial cancer. Postoperative histopathology reveals involvement of lymph nodes. Considering her current status and the procedures performed, which of the following statements is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphadenectomy in endometrial cancer is essential for determining the stage and planning subsequent treatment.

 

  • The patient has stage IIIc disease, she will require adjuvant EBRT +/- chemotherapy
  • Lymphadenectomy plays a critical role in the surgical management of endometrial cancer.
  • It provides vital information on the extent of disease spread, particularly to lymph nodes, which is crucial for accurate staging.
  • This process subsequently informs decisions about the necessity and extent of further treatments such as chemotherapy or radiotherapy to manage any residual disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient is classified as having stage IIIb endometrial cancer: Stage IIIb specifically refers to invasion into the vagina or parametrium, which is not indicated by lymph node involvement alone. This typically corresponds to stage IIIC if only lymph nodes are involved.

 

Option B. No additional treatment is necessary since lymphadenectomy has been performed: This is incorrect as the detection of lymph node metastases often requires further adjuvant therapy to address potential residual disease.

 

Option D. Adjuvant vaginal brachytherapy will be required as part of her treatment plan: While this could be a component of her treatment for local control, it cannot be definitively recommended without more specific information about the location, grade of the tumor, and overall treatment strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphadenectomy in the management of endometrial cancer is crucial for accurately determining the stage of the disease and informing subsequent treatment decisions.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to a pediatric endocrinologist for evaluation of delayed puberty. The doctor discusses various hormonal factors that contribute to the initiation of puberty. Which hormone is known to play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptin

 

  • Leptin, a hormone produced by adipose (fat) cells, plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty, particularly in signaling the sufficiency of energy stores necessary for the onset of reproductive capability.
  • Leptin levels increase with body fat and signal to the hypothalamus that the body has adequate energy reserves to support the energy demands of reproduction.
  • This hormonal signal helps trigger the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis to initiate the production of sex hormones and thus start puberty. The presence of adequate leptin levels is crucial for the normal timing of puberty, especially in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH): GnRH (Gonadotropin-releasing hormone) is not just permissive but rather the direct trigger for puberty, as it stimulates the pituitary to release LH (luteinizing hormone) and FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone), which are essential for sexual development and reproductive function.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin plays a supportive role in overall growth and development and does impact puberty indirectly by influencing body energy stores and metabolism; however, it does not have as direct or recognized a permissive role in the initiation of puberty as leptin.

 

Option D. Growth Hormone (GH): GH (Growth Hormone) is critical for overall growth and has roles in the development of bone and muscle, but its role in triggering puberty is less direct compared to the role of leptin in indicating energy sufficiency for reproductive functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leptin is crucial for signaling that the body has adequate energy reserves necessary for the onset of puberty, playing a permissive role by influencing the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis to begin sexual and reproductive development.
  • Understanding leptin’s role in puberty helps in evaluating cases of delayed puberty related to nutritional and metabolic issues.

questions.text:
For which of the following parasites is NNN medium used for isolation?

 

  1. Leishmania donovani
  2. Giardia
  3. E. histolytica
  4. Trichomonas vaginalis
  5. Trypanosoma cruzi
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 5

 

  • NNN medium is particularly useful for the culture of obligate intracellular parasites such as Leishmania spp. and Trypanosoma cruzi.
  • It allows for the isolation and growth of these parasites by providing an environment that supports their unique growth requirements.

 

1. Leishmania donovani: True, NNN medium is traditionally used for the isolation of Leishmania species from specimens such as bone marrow or splenic aspirates.

 

5. Trypanosoma cruzi: True, NNN medium can also be used for the cultivation of Trypanosoma cruzi from blood samples.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Giardia: Giardia is not typically isolated on NNN medium. It can be diagnosed from stool specimens using different techniques, including microscopic examination and antigen tests.

 

3. E. histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is also not isolated on NNN medium; stool microscopic examination and antigen tests are commonly used.

 

4. Trichomonas vaginalis: This parasite is not cultivated on NNN medium. It is often diagnosed by wet mount microscopy or culture in specialized media for Trichomonas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NNN Media is used for culture of Leishmania and Trypanosoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, who is a chronic smoker, presents to the clinic with hypertension and obesity with marked hyperpigmentation. Which of the following will help in diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dexamethasone Suppression Test

 

  • The presentation of hypertension, obesity, and marked hyperpigmentation is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome, which is a condition characterized by excessive cortisol levels.
  • The Dexamethasone Suppression Test is used to assess the body's response to synthetic glucocorticoids and evaluate the function of the adrenal glands and pituitary in the regulation of cortisol, helping diagnose conditions like Cushing's syndrome.
  • This test involves administering dexamethasone and measuring subsequent cortisol levels to see if they decrease appropriately, indicating a normal or abnormal feedback loop.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid Function Test: This test measures the levels of thyroid hormones, which would be relevant if there were symptoms indicative of thyroid dysfunction, such as abnormal metabolism or thermoregulation, but it does not directly address the symptoms presented by this patient.

 

Option B. PTH levels: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels would help diagnose parathyroid-related conditions affecting calcium metabolism, not directly relevant to hyperpigmentation, hypertension, or the suspected hypercortisolism.

 

Option D. Oral Glucose Tolerance Test: While this test is used to diagnose diabetes by assessing how well the body handles a set amount of glucose, it is less relevant to directly diagnosing the cause of hyperpigmentation and hypertension in the context suggested by the patient’s symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with obesity, hypertension, and marked hyperpigmentation, particularly if there is a background of chronic smoking which may exacerbate some symptoms, the Dexamethasone Suppression Test is appropriate to evaluate for Cushing's syndrome, a condition of excess cortisol production.

choices.text: It is the dilated posterior end of superior sagittal sinus
It is related below with the occipital sinus
It also receives the inferior sagittal sinus
It is usually continuous with the right transverse sinus

questions.text: Which among the following statements is not true about the pointed structure in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It also receives the inferior sagittal sinus

 

  • The confluence of sinuses, indicated by the blue arrow in the image, does not directly receive the inferior sagittal sinus.
  • The inferior sagittal sinus typically drains into the straight sinus, which then contributes to the confluence of sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the dilated posterior end of superior sagittal sinus: The dilated posterior end of the superior sagittal sinus indeed contributes to the confluence of sinuses, also known as the torcular Herophili, where multiple dural venous sinuses join.

 

Option B. It is related below with the occipital sinus: The confluence of sinuses is anatomically related to the occipital sinus, which is smaller and often variable in size and presence.

 

Option D. It is usually continuous with the right transverse sinus: While there is some variability in venous anatomy, the confluence of sinuses is typically continuous with the transverse sinuses, with a common tendency to be more continuous with the right transverse sinus due to the dominant drainage pattern on that side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to test the understanding of the cerebral venous sinus anatomy, particularly the relationships and connections of the confluence of sinuses.
  • Recognizing these relationships is important in neuroanatomy as it relates to the drainage of cerebral blood and can have clinical implications in conditions that affect cerebral venous circulation, such as thrombosis or sinus pressure dynamics during neurosurgery.

choices.text: Voltage-gated calcium channelopathy
Dysfunction of the sodium potassium pump
Voltage-gated potassium channelopathy impacting depolarization
Voltage-gated sodium channelopathy

questions.text: In a patient exhibiting neurological symptoms characterized by an impairment in the positive feedback loop crucial for neuronal depolarization, the failure to reach the firing or threshold level (-55 mV) is attributed to an underlying ion channel dysfunction. Which ion channelopathy would be most likely responsible for this specific impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Voltage-gated sodium channelopathy

 

  • Neuronal depolarization and the ability to reach the firing threshold largely depend on the function of voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • These channels are responsible for the rapid influx of sodium ions (Na+) into the neuron during the initial phase of the action potential.
  • If these channels are dysfunctional, the rapid depolarization necessary to reach the threshold potential of approximately -55 mV cannot occur, preventing the neuron from firing an action potential.
  • This type of ion channel dysfunction can lead to various neurological symptoms due to the inability of neurons to properly transmit signals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voltage-gated calcium channelopathy: Voltage-gated calcium channelopathies can affect neurotransmitter release at synapses and muscle contraction but are not typically responsible for the initial depolarization phase of the action potential in neurons.

 

Option B. Dysfunction of the sodium potassium pump: Dysfunction of the sodium-potassium pump (Na+/K+ ATPase) affects the maintenance of the resting membrane potential and the restoration phase after an action potential but does not directly impede the depolarization process to reach threshold potential.

 

Option C. Voltage-gated potassium channelopathy impacting depolarization: Voltage-gated potassium channels are involved in repolarization and the return of the membrane potential to its resting state after an action potential. They do not play a direct role in the depolarization phase that reaches the threshold.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Voltage-gated sodium channels are critical for the depolarization phase of neuronal action potentials.
  • Dysfunction in these channels can prevent the neuron from reaching the firing threshold, leading to a failure to transmit electrical signals and resulting in various neurological impairments.

questions.text: A male patient with acute psychosis on haloperidol 20 mg/day for the last three days experiences tongue protrusion, oculogyric crisis, limb and trunk stiffness, and abnormal posture lasting 25- 30 minutes, without loss of consciousness. The symptoms promptly resolved after administration of diphenhydramine HCl. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute dystonia

 

  • Acute dystonia is an early-onset extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics, presenting with sudden, often painful muscle spasms and abnormal postures, as seen in this patient.
  • The rapid resolution with diphenhydramine, an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tardive dyskinesia: Typically occurs after long-term use of antipsychotics and involves repetitive, involuntary movements, not the acute presentation described.

 

Option B. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS): NMS is a serious condition associated with antipsychotics that involves fever, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, and altered mental status, which are not described here.

 

Option C. Akathisia: Characterized by an inner restlessness and the need to move constantly, not the fixed, abnormal postures typical of dystonia.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Acute dystonia is a potential early complication of antipsychotic therapy, characterized by sudden abnormal postures and muscle stiffness, which can be effectively treated with anticholinergic medications like diphenhydramine.

questions.text: Amino acid responsible for Thioredoxin reductase activation:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Selenocysteine

 

  • Thioredoxin reductase is a selenium-containing enzyme, and the active site of the enzyme includes the amino acid selenocysteine, which is crucial for its activity.
  • Selenocysteine is known as the 21st amino acid and is unique in that it contains selenium, which is necessary for the reduction of the active site disulfide in thioredoxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serine: Serine is a non-essential amino acid and does not contain selenium. It is not specifically responsible for the activation of thioredoxin reductase.

 

Option C. Cysteine: While cysteine is important in many redox reactions in proteins due to its thiol group, it is selenocysteine that is specifically responsible for thioredoxin reductase activation.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine is a non-essential amino acid and plays no direct role in the activation of thioredoxin reductase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selenocysteine is the amino acid responsible for the activation of thioredoxin reductase due to its unique selenium-containing property, which is essential for the enzyme's redox activity.

choices.text: Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood
Dysmenorrhea is a common presentation

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease due to tuberculosis. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with infertility

 

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to tuberculosis often leads to scarring and blockage of the fallopian tubes, which can significantly impair fertility.
  • This is one of the more severe long-term consequences of the disease, making infertility a common issue associated with tubercular PID.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood: While theoretically possible, it is not commonly practiced or reliable for diagnosing genital tuberculosis.


Option C. Ectopic pregnancy is common: While tubal damage due to tuberculosis can predispose to ectopic pregnancies, it is not as common as infertility.
 

Option D. Dysmenorrhea is a common presentation: Dysmenorrhea is not a typical symptom of tubercular PID; instead, menstrual irregularities and pelvic pain are more characteristic.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Tubercular PID is a severe form of PID with significant long-term reproductive consequences.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with recurrent painful oral lesions, as shown in the image. She reports that the lesions reappear especially during periods of stress or illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes labialis

 

  • The lesions shown are characteristic of herpes labialis, commonly known as "cold sores," which are caused by the herpes simplex virus.
  • They typically manifest as painful, recurrent vesicular lesions on the lips and perioral skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpangina: Typically caused by Coxsackieviruses, herpangina presents with fever, sore throat, and vesicles on the oropharynx, not the lips.

 

Option B. Ludwig angina: An acute bacterial infection usually secondary to a dental infection; it is characterized by a firm swelling and erythema of the submandibular and sublingual areas, not vesicular lesions on the lips.

 

Option D. Trench mouth: Also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG), trench mouth presents with painful bleeding gums and ulcerations, not the vesicular lesions seen in herpes labialis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recurrent painful tiny vesicular ulcers surrounding lips suggestive of herpes labialis.

choices.text: Sudden loss of muscle tone

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman visits the clinic, reporting excessive daytime sleepiness, vivid hallucinations when falling asleep and upon waking, and difficulty initiating sleep at night. Which of the following is NOT a characteristic symptom of narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catalepsy

 

  • Catalepsy refers to a physical condition where individuals maintain rigid body positions for extended periods, which is not a symptom of narcolepsy.
  • It is often confused with cataplexy, a common symptom of narcolepsy involving sudden, brief episodes of muscle weakness triggered by strong emotions.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Sleep paralysis: This involves an inability to move or speak at the onset of sleep or upon waking and is a characteristic symptom of narcolepsy.

 

Option B. Sudden loss of muscle tone: Known as cataplexy, this is a hallmark of narcolepsy, often triggered by strong emotional responses.

 

Option C. Hypnopompic hallucinations: These are vivid perceptual experiences occurring upon waking, common in narcolepsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone) is a characteristic symptom of narcolepsy, catalepsy is not associated with narcolepsy and pertains to unrelated conditions.

choices.text: Depends on level of concentration of HbS

questions.text: In Hb S, glutamic acid is replaced by valine. What will be its electrophoretic mobility?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased

 

  • In hemoglobin S (HbS), which is associated with sickle cell anemia, glutamic acid is replaced by valine at the sixth position of the beta-globin chain.
  • This substitution of a negatively charged amino acid (glutamic acid) with a neutral amino acid (valine) reduces the overall negative charge of the hemoglobin molecule.
  • Since electrophoretic mobility is influenced by the charge of the molecules, HbS moves slower towards the positively charged anode in an electric field compared to normal hemoglobin (HbA), indicating a decreased electrophoretic mobility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased: This is incorrect because the replacement of glutamic acid with valine reduces the negative charge, not increases it.

 

Option C. No change: This is not accurate because the substitution does affect the charge of the hemoglobin molecule, thus altering its electrophoretic mobility.

 

Option D. Depends on level of concentration of HbS: The electrophoretic mobility change due to the amino acid substitution is not dependent on the concentration of HbS but on its altered charge profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The substitution of glutamic acid with valine in HbS leads to a decrease in electrophoretic mobility due to the reduced negative charge of the hemoglobin molecule.

choices.text: Hypoglycemia is less common than with sulfonylureas
It acts by releasing insulin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nateglinide is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It decreases insulin resistance

 

  • Nateglinide is a meglitinide derivative that acts by stimulating the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells.
  • It primarily targets post-prandial hyperglycemia by promoting a rapid, short-lived increase in insulin secretion immediately following meals.
  • This mechanism reduces the risk of hypoglycemia compared to sulfonylureas, which have a longer duration of action.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hypoglycemia is less common than with sulfonylureas: This statement is true because nateglinide’s action is shorter in duration, limiting the period during which hypoglycemia could occur.

 

Option C. It acts by releasing insulin: This is accurate. Nateglinide stimulates insulin secretion through its action on the pancreatic beta-cell K_ATP channels, similar to sulfonylureas but with a quicker onset and shorter effect.

 

Option D. Decreases post-prandial hyperglycemia: True, as its primary therapeutic use is to control blood sugar spikes that occur after meals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nateglinide does not affect insulin resistance; instead, it enhances insulin secretion from the pancreas.
  • This action specifically helps in managing post-meal glucose levels, making it beneficial for controlling post-prandial hyperglycemia in patients with type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: In a public health survey conducted in rural Odisha, a 36-year-old woman is found to have a hemoglobin (Hb) level of 15.0 g/dl. This finding is particularly noteworthy as the survey data shows that the mean Hb level among the women in this area is 13.5 g/dl, with a standard deviation of 1.5 g/dl. To contextualize the woman's Hb level within the study's data, the researcher uses the concept of Z-scores. Based on this information, what is the Z-score for this woman's hemoglobin level?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1.0

 

 

Calculation:

 

= (15.0−13.5)/1.5=1.0

 

Educational Objective:

 

Z Score (Standard Score):

 

  • Is also known as ‘normal deviate’
  • Is difference of a value from group mean, in terms of how many times of SD (s)

 

 

  • The standard score indicates how many standard deviations an observation is above or below the mean

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of severe pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her left eye. She has a history of similar episodes in the past. On slit-lamp examination, the ophthalmologist observes a finding as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the description of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex dendritic ulcer

 

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection of the eye can lead to a characteristic dendritic ulcer, which appears as a branching lesion with terminal bulbs on the corneal surface, visible under fluorescein staining during slit-lamp examination. This is a classic finding for HSV keratitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fungal keratitis: Fungal keratitis typically presents with a feathery, indistinct edge and infiltrates that are more diffuse than the sharp, well-defined margins of a dendritic ulcer.

 

Option C. Bacterial corneal ulcer: Bacterial corneal ulcer generally appears as an opaque, round or irregular stromal infiltrate, often with a more purulent discharge compared to viral causes.

 

Option D. Acanthamoeba keratitis: Acanthamoeba keratitis may show ring infiltrates and is often associated with contact lens wear in non-compliant individuals, presenting with severe pain out of proportion to clinical findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognition of a herpes simplex dendritic ulcer on slit-lamp examination is crucial for the timely initiation of antiviral therapy, which is effective in managing symptoms and preventing progression of the disease.
  • It is important to differentiate it from other types of keratitis, as treatment varies significantly depending on the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with history of occasional alcohol consumption, presented to the casualty with acute abdominal pain, distention of abdomen and vomiting. On x-ray, the following was noticed. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CECT abdomen immediately

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of acute small bowel obstruction. The dilated air fluid levels in step up pattern suggest mechanical block.
  • Thus, CECT is needed to be done immediately to identify the site and the status of the bowel ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum lipase: Serum lipase is done when suspecting acute pancreatitis, which is unlikely here.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: Exploratory laparotomy may be done depending on etiology of acute obstruction, which would require CECT to confirm prior.

 

Option D. CECT abdomen after 72 hours: It is done for assessing extent of necrosis in acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In case of acute mechanical small bowel obstruction, CECT is required to assess site of obstruction and presence of ischemia.

choices.text: Stool trophozoites are essential for diagnosis
Causes disease in the brain
Causes disease in the liver

questions.text: A physician is discussing the clinical presentation and diagnosis of Entamoeba histolytica infection with medical residents. He mentions several facts about the parasite and its disease manifestations. Which of the following statements about Entamoeba histolytica is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stool trophozoites are essential for diagnosis

 

  • The detection of stool trophozoites is not essential for the diagnosis of Entamoeba histolytica.
  • While trophozoites can be found in the stool of infected individuals, they are not always present, especially in asymptomatic carriers.
  • Diagnosis can also be made by finding cysts in stool samples, serological tests, and imaging studies, especially in cases of invasive disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mostly (85%) are asymptomatic: True, the majority of individuals infected with Entamoeba histolytica are asymptomatic carriers.

 

Option C. Causes disease in the brain: True, although rare, Entamoeba histolytica can cause extraintestinal disease, including brain abscesses, when trophozoites disseminate through the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Causes disease in the liver: True, the most common extraintestinal manifestation of Entamoeba histolytica infection is liver abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stool trophozoites are usually found in acute stage of amoebic dysentery and indicate active infection but they soon disappear and are not found in later stage of dysentery or carriers or in invasive amebiasis.
  • Hence stool trophozoites are NOT essential for diagnosis; however their presence confirms active stage of amoebic dysentery.

questions.text: A hospital is auditing its waste management system to ensure compliance with biomedical waste regulations. Match the items listed in Column A with the correct color-coded dustbins in Column B for disposal.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

1. Catheter: Catheters are considered contaminated and should be disposed of in the red bin, which is for contaminated waste (e.g., plastics).

 

2. Torn registration forms: Paper waste like patient records and registration forms should be disposed of in the green/black bin, which is for general waste.

 

3. Expired vaccine: Expired or discarded medicines and vaccines should go into the yellow bin, designated for pharmaceutical waste.

 

4. Antibiotic bottle: Glass bottles are typically disposed of in the blue bin, which is for glassware and metallic body implants.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 26 G Peripheral venous catheter

questions.text: During a complicated delivery, a newborn requires immediate vascular access due to respiratory distress and suspected sepsis. The neonatal resuscitation team must quickly establish intravenous access. Which of the following is the preferred method for establishing emergency IV access in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical venous access

 

  • This method is the preferred emergency access in neonates in the delivery room. It provides rapid, reliable access to the central circulation using the remnant umbilical vein, which remains patent for about a week after birth and is ideal for emergency infusion of medications and fluids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 26 G Peripheral venous catheter: While commonly used for IV access in older children and adults, establishing a peripheral IV line in a neonate, especially under emergency conditions, can be challenging due to their small vein size.

 

Option B. Central venous catheter: This type of access provides long-term IV access but is not typically the first choice in emergency situations due to the time and skill required for placement.

 

Option D. Intraosseous infusion: This is a viable emergency alternative when other forms of vascular access are not feasible. However, it is generally considered after attempts at umbilical or peripheral access fail.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Umbilical venous access is often the fastest and most efficient method for establishing emergency intravenous access in neonates in the delivery room.
  • It is particularly useful for rapid administration of medications and fluids in critical situations.

choices.text: TRAM (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous) Flap
DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator) Flap
Anterolateral thigh flap
Latissimus dorsi flap

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes mastectomy for breast cancer. She discusses options for breast reconstruction with her surgeon. During the discussion, the surgeon mentions various techniques, as mentioned below. Which of these options is not a free flap for breast reconstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Latissimus dorsi flap

 

  • The correct answer is D, Latissimus dorsi flap, because it is not a free flap; it remains attached to its blood supply during the transfer to the chest for breast reconstruction.
  • This is not a free flap but a pedicled flap, meaning it remains attached to its original blood supply as it is moved to the breast area. It involves taking muscle, skin, and fat from the upper back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TRAM (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous) Flap: This flap involves transferring skin, fat, and part of the underlying rectus abdominis muscle to reconstruct the breast. It can be done as a free flap or a pedicled flap.

 

Option B. DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator) Flap: Similar to the free TRAM flap but spares the rectus muscle. It uses the skin and fat from the lower abdomen, along with the accompanying blood vessels, and is reattached to the chest blood vessels to form a new breast mound.

 

Option C. Anterolateral thigh (ALT) Flap: This flap uses skin and fat from the thigh to reconstruct the breast. It is less commonly used than abdominal tissue but is an option for patients who do not have enough abdominal tissue or prefer not to use it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The aim is to familiarize with various flap options for breast reconstruction, differentiating between free and pedicled flaps.
  • A free flap involves detaching tissue from one area of the body with its blood supply and reattaching it to blood vessels at the reconstruction site using microsurgery.
  • In contrast, a pedicled flap maintains its original blood supply during the transfer.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman in labor requests epidural analgesia for pain management. The anesthesiologist prepares to perform the procedure and selects a specific needle designed for this purpose. Identify the needle:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuohy needle

 

  • The Tuohy needle is specifically designed for epidural anesthesia.
  • It is characterized by its curved, blunt tip which is designed to navigate safely through the epidural space, minimizing the risk of puncturing the dura mater.
  • The unique curvature of the Tuohy needle allows for more precise placement of the catheter within the epidural space, facilitating effective and localized delivery of anesthetic agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal needle: Spinal needle is used for subarachnoid blocks where the anesthetic is injected into the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C. Quincke needle: Quincke needle, often used for lumbar punctures, features a sharp bevel tip that can cause more dural fibers to be cut, which may increase the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

 

Option D. Whitacre needle: Whitacre needle is a type of spinal needle with a pencil-point tip designed to part dural fibers rather than cutting them, reducing the likelihood of cerebrospinal fluid leaks and subsequent headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Tuohy needle's design is optimized for epidural placements, enhancing the safety and efficacy of epidural anesthesia, especially in delicate procedures such as labor analgesia.

questions.text:
After sustaining injuries in a road traffic accident, a patient presented with a type IIIa open fracture of the tibia. Arrange the following external fixators in decreasing order of their stability (highest to lowest).

 

  1. Ilizarov fixator
  2. Uniplanar with a single rod
  3. Uniplanar with double rod
  4. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1>4>3>2

 

The Ilizarov fixator is known for its versatility and stability. It is a circular frame that allows for multiplanar correction and stabilization, which is especially useful in complex fractures or those with a significant soft-tissue component.

 

  • 1. Ilizarov fixator: Offers the highest stability due to its circular design and multiplanar adjustability.
  • 4. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod: Provides more stability than uniplanar fixators because it involves fixation in two planes.
  • 3. Uniplanar with double rod: More stable than a single rod due to the additional rod, which offers more support and resistance to bending and rotational forces.
  • 2. Uniplanar with a single rod: The least stable configuration because it involves fixation in only one plane and has less resistance to forces compared to the other configurations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1>2>3>4: Incorrect because the biplanar frame provides more stability than uniplanar fixators.

 

Option B. 2>4>3>1: Incorrect as the Ilizarov fixator is more stable than a uniplanar fixator with a single rod.

 

Option D. 2>3>1>4: Incorrect because it doesn’t recognize the superior stability of the Ilizarov fixator and biplanar constructs over uniplanar constructs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Ilizarov fixator offers the highest stability among external fixators for treating complex fractures, followed by biplanar frames, uniplanar with double rods, and lastly, uniplanar with a single rod.

choices.text: Start monotherapy with anti-TNF alpha drugs
Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.text: A 42-year patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) has been on methotrexate, steroids, and NSAIDs for 5 months, but the disease activity remains unchanged. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine

 

  • Adding sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine is a common strategy in the management of RA when there is insufficient response to initial therapy with methotrexate, steroids, and NSAIDs.
  • This approach is part of a treatment strategy known as "combination therapy," which can be more effective in controlling disease activity than monotherapy or continued existing therapies alone.
  • The combination of sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine with methotrexate is known to enhance the therapeutic effects and potentially provide better control of disease progression.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Continue methotrexate and steroids: This would not be advisable as the patient has already shown no improvement with the current regimen over a significant period.

 

Option B. Start monotherapy with anti-TNF alpha drugs: While anti-TNF therapy is a powerful option for RA management, it is typically considered after trying combination traditional DMARDs (Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drugs) or when there is a high disease activity or poor prognostic factors. It may also be considered here, but it is generally costlier and has higher risk profiles.

 

Option D. Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate: Although switching to parenteral methotrexate can improve drug efficacy due to better bioavailability, it usually applies to cases of gastrointestinal intolerance or suboptimal absorption, not necessarily unchanged disease activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of RA where initial therapy with methotrexate, steroids, and NSAIDs does not halt disease progression, adding other traditional DMARDs such as sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine can be an effective next step before considering more aggressive treatments like biologic agents.

questions.text: In a randomized clinical trial, 1000 healthy women between ages 60 and 65 were given a new drug and another 1000 a placebo to prevent breast cancer. After 5 years, 10 women who received the new drug and 40 who received the placebo developed breast cancer. What is the relative risk of developing breast cancer in patients exposed to the new drug compared to those who received the placebo?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 25%

 

In the given question,

 

 

Thus, considering new drug as exposure (placebo as non-exposure) and development of breast cancer as disease,

 

Iexp = 10 per 1000 = 0.01

Inon-exp = 40 per 1000 = 0.04

Thus, RR = Iexp/Inon-exp = 0.01/0.04 = 0.25

(ideally RR is a ratio – MUST NOT be expressed as percentage)

 

Interpretation: New drug is efficacious in prevention of breast cancer; new drug is protective for breast cancer

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor
  • Relative Risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is 2-PAM (Pralidoxime) useful in the treatment of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malathion Poisoning

 

  • 2-PAM (Pralidoxime) is a cholinesterase reactivator and is used as an antidote in cases of organophosphate poisoning, such as malathion poisoning.
  • Organophosphates inhibit acetylcholinesterase, leading to excessive accumulation of acetylcholine at cholinergic synapses, causing symptoms of cholinergic excess.
  • 2-PAM works by reactivating acetylcholinesterase, thereby restoring its activity and reducing the levels of acetylcholine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paracetamol overdose: 2-PAM is not effective in the treatment of paracetamol overdose. The antidote for paracetamol overdose is N-acetylcysteine.

 

Option B. DDT Poisoning: DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is an insecticide, but 2-PAM is not indicated for its poisoning. DDT poisoning is managed through supportive care and decontamination.

 

Option D. Lead Poisoning: 2-PAM is not used in the treatment of lead poisoning. Chelation therapy with agents like dimercaprol (BAL) or EDTA is the mainstay of treatment for lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 2-PAM (Pralidoxime) is specifically indicated in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, such as malathion poisoning.

questions.text: An adult ICU patient presented with respiratory distress and frothy pink sputum. A CXR reveal is given below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardiogenic pulmonary edema

 

  • The CXR shows characteristic bilateral alveolar infiltrates with a central distribution that creates a "bat wing" appearance, which is a classic sign of frank pulmonary edema.
  • The clinical symptoms of acute respiratory distress and frothy pink sputum corroborate this finding, as they are indicative of fluid overload in the alveolar spaces typically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • This condition often results from acute left ventricular failure, which leads to increased pressure in the pulmonary capillaries, causing fluid transudation into the alveolar spaces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A chest X-ray showing bilateral alveolar infiltrates with a central distribution sparing the lung periphery, along with clinical signs of acute respiratory distress and frothy pink sputum, is indicative of frank pulmonary edema with a 'bat wing' appearance, most commonly associated with cardiogenic causes.

choices.text: Heparin should be discontinued immediately
Alternative anticoagulant such as lepirudin should be administered
Low molecular weight heparins should be avoided
Heparin should be replaced with Warfarin

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heparin should be replaced with Warfarin

 

  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a serious immune-mediated complication of heparin therapy, characterized by a decrease in platelet count and an increased risk of thrombosis.
  • Warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist, should not be used as an alternative anticoagulant in HIT because it can paradoxically increase the risk of thrombosis during the initial phase of treatment due to protein C depletion.
  • Therefore, heparin should not be replaced with warfarin in patients with HIT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin should be discontinued immediately: Heparin should be discontinued immediately upon suspicion of HIT to prevent further platelet activation and thrombosis.

 

Option B. Alternative anticoagulant such as lepirudin should be administered: Alternative anticoagulants, such as direct thrombin inhibitors like lepirudin or argatroban, are recommended for anticoagulation in patients with HIT because they do not interact with platelet factor 4/heparin complexes and are not associated with worsening thrombocytopenia or thrombotic complications.

 

Option C. Low molecular weight heparins should be avoided:  Low molecular weight heparins (LMWH) should be avoided in patients with HIT because they have similar antigenic properties to unfractionated heparin and can cross-react with HIT antibodies, potentially worsening the thrombotic complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), heparin should be discontinued immediately, and alternative anticoagulants such as lepirudin should be administered.
  • Low molecular weight heparins should be avoided, and warfarin should not be used as an alternative anticoagulant in HIT due to the risk of paradoxical thrombosis.

questions.text: After administering a drug for an acute migraine attack, a patient experienced nausea, vomiting, and developed tingling and numbness in the fingertip, which also turned blue. Which drug is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dihydroergotamine

 

  • Dihydroergotamine, a drug used for migraine attacks, is associated with side effects such as nausea, vomiting, and peripheral ischemia, which can lead to symptoms like tingling, numbness, and a blue discoloration of the extremities.
  • These symptoms result from its mechanism of action, which involves vasoconstriction of peripheral and cranial blood vessels.
  • This vasoconstrictive effect can reduce blood flow to extremities, leading to the noted side effects.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: While it is commonly used for pain relief, including mild migraines, and can cause gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, it does not typically cause peripheral vasoconstriction or symptoms such as tingling and blue discoloration of the fingers.

 

Option B. Butorphanol: This is a narcotic pain reliever used for severe migraine. It can cause nausea and vomiting but is not linked to peripheral ischemic effects like those described.

 

Option D. Sumatriptan: Another migraine medication that can cause tingling and numbness, but unlike dihydroergotamine, sumatriptan is less likely to cause severe peripheral vasoconstriction leading to blue discoloration of the extremities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dihydroergotamine can cause severe vasoconstriction effects, leading to symptoms like tingling, numbness, and blue discoloration of the extremities, alongside more common side effects such as nausea and vomiting.
  • This profile is particularly significant when considering side effects in the treatment of migraine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a widespread erythematous rash over his back characterized by fine scaling and distinct areas of unaffected skin, or "islands of sparing." Considering Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) as a potential diagnosis, which of the following clinical signs would be most supportive of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perifollicular Erythema

 

  • Is a classic finding in PRP, often observed as a reddish halo around hair follicles on the affected areas and is one of the supportive signs of this diagnosis.

 

 

IMAGE: Orange–red follicular papules with coalescence into large scaly plaques, in addition to islands of sparing; follicular hyperkeratosis is often easier to appreciate within the relatively spared islands

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Keratoderma blenorrhagica: It is typically associated with reactive arthritis, not PRP, and presents with hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and soles.

 

 

Option B. The Koebner phenomenon: This refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on the site of trauma and can be seen in various dermatologic conditions like psoriasis and lichen planus, but it is not specific to PRP.

 

Option D. Nail Pitting: It is commonly seen in psoriasis, and while nail changes can occur in PRP, they are not as diagnostic as perifollicular erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When evaluating a patient with a scaly erythematous rash and islands of sparing, identification of perifollicular erythema can support the diagnosis of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris, a condition that requires a distinct approach to management compared to other papulosquamous diseases.

questions.text:
A newborn is assessed at 1 minute after birth. Calculate the APGAR score based on the following findings:

 

  • Heart rate: 110 beats per minute
  • Respiratory effort: Strong cry
  • Muscle tone: Some flexion of arms and legs
  • Reflex irritability: Grimace on stimulation
  • Color: Body pink, extremities blue
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 7

 

Here’s how each component of the APGAR score is calculated:

 

  • Heart Rate (0-2 points): Over 100 beats per minute earns 2 points.
  • Respiratory Effort (0-2 points): A strong cry earns 2 points, indicating good respiratory effort.
  • Muscle Tone (0-2 points): Some flexion of arms and legs earns 1 point (full active motion would earn 2 points).
  • Reflex Irritability (0-2 points): Grimace on stimulation earns 1 point (cry would earn 2 points).
  • Color (0-2 points): Body pink but extremities blue earns 1 point (completely pink earns 2 points).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The APGAR score is a valuable tool for assessing the immediate health of newborns at 1 and 5 minutes after birth.
  • Scores of 7 to 10 indicate generally normal, but newborns with scores under 7 may require medical interventions.
  • It assesses heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, reflex irritability, and color, each contributing to the overall score to help guide initial neonatal care.

choices.text: Increase in Renal Blood Flow
Decrease in Colloid Osmotic Pressure
Decrease in Glomerular Filtration Rate

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of extreme stress and anxiety. He reports a recent traumatic event and is experiencing a "fight or flight" response. Which of the following statements regarding the effect of strong sympathetic activation on the kidneys is most accurate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decrease in Glomerular Filtration Rate

 

  • During a strong sympathetic activation, such as during a "fight or flight" response triggered by extreme stress and anxiety, the body prioritizes blood flow to essential organs (like the heart and muscles) and away from less critical areas under acute conditions, including the kidneys.
  • This redirection is facilitated by the constriction of renal blood vessels, leading to a decrease in renal blood flow.
  • A reduced renal blood flow lowers the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), which is the rate at which blood is filtered in the kidneys.
  • This is a protective mechanism to preserve fluid and electrolytes during times of acute stress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in Renal Blood Flow: This is incorrect as sympathetic activation typically causes vasoconstriction in the renal arteries, thereby decreasing renal blood flow, not increasing it.

 

Option B. Decrease in Colloid Osmotic Pressure: This option is unrelated to the direct effects of sympathetic activation on the kidneys. Colloid osmotic pressure is more directly related to protein levels in the blood and is not significantly affected by short-term changes in sympathetic tone.

 

Option C. Increase in Filtration Fraction: While filtration fraction (the ratio of GFR to renal plasma flow) could technically increase if renal plasma flow decreases more than GFR, the most direct and significant effect of sympathetic activation is the decrease in GFR itself, not necessarily an increase in filtration fraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During strong sympathetic activation, such as in a stress response, there is a decrease in glomerular filtration rate due to vasoconstriction of renal blood vessels.
  • This response helps the body conserve fluids and maintain blood pressure, which is crucial during emergency situations where survival mechanisms are prioritized.

questions.text: During an examination of a 7-year-old girl presenting with fever, sore throat, and a rash, you note the sign as seen in the image below. Which of the following signs is being described, commonly associated with scarlet fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Filatov's sign

 

This sign describes circumoral pallor in the presence of a bright red rash on the face, which is commonly seen in scarlet fever. It helps differentiate the rash of scarlet fever from other similar presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pastia's sign: Characteristic of scarlet fever, Pastia's sign involves lines of red or darker skin coloration that form in the creases of the skin, especially in the axillary, antecubital, and groin areas.

 

 

Option C. Sandpaper sign: This sign refers to the texture of the rash in scarlet fever, which feels rough to the touch, resembling sandpaper. It is not specifically about facial appearance.

 

Option D. Koplik's spots: These small, white spots on a red background are found inside the mouth and are pathognomonic for measles, not scarlet fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Filatovs sign describes circumoral pallor in the presence of a bright red rash on the face, which is commonly seen in scarlet fever.

questions.text: An infectious disease specialist is giving a lecture on antigenic variation and its role in the epidemiology of influenza viruses. Antigenic variation is a mechanism by which influenza viruses evade the immune response and is characterized by changes in the antigenic proteins hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). Which type of influenza virus is least associated with antigenic variation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Influenza type C

 

  • Antigenic variation is a well-known feature of both Influenza A and B viruses, where they undergo changes through two main processes: antigenic drift and antigenic shift.
  • However, Influenza type C is less likely to undergo such variations compared to types A and B, largely due to its limited impact on human disease and a more stable genome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influenza type A: This type is known for both antigenic drift and shift, which can lead to significant epidemics and pandemics.

 

Option B. Influenza type B: While antigenic variation occurs, it typically only undergoes antigenic drift and not shift, so the changes are less dramatic than in type A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Influenza virus type A and to less extent type B undergo antigenic variation, which is of two types: antigenic shift and drift. Type C influenza virus is stable.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis, now presents with epistaxis, bilateral cavitary lung lesions, and renal failure. Given these clinical findings, what will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tissue Biopsy

 

  • Given the presentation of recurrent sinusitis, epistaxis, bilateral cavitary lung lesions, and renal failure, a tissue biopsy is essential for confirming the diagnosis.
  • While serological tests like c-ANCA can suggest certain types of vasculitis such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), a tissue biopsy provides definitive histopathological evidence, confirming the presence of vasculitis, granulomas, or other specific pathological changes directly linked to the underlying disease.
  • This direct visualization and analysis of tissue are crucial, especially in complex cases where the diagnosis remains uncertain after initial testing or where other conditions might mimic similar symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. c-ANCA: While highly specific for GPA, c-ANCA may not confirm the diagnosis definitively, especially in cases where the clinical picture is atypical or mixed with features suggestive of other diseases.

 

Option B. p-ANCA: Associated with other forms of vasculitis and less specific to GPA, it is not the best confirmatory test in the presence of symptoms typical of GPA.

 

Option C. DLCO: Useful in assessing lung function but not diagnostic for types of vasculitis or underlying causes of lung and renal pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with complex multi-system symptoms such as recurrent sinusitis, epistaxis, lung cavitations, and renal failure, a tissue biopsy is crucial for obtaining a definitive diagnosis, distinguishing between similar conditions, and guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient undergoes elective open cholecystectomy after receiving prophylactic antibiotics. What is the expected rate of surgical site infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3%

 

  • After the administration of prophylactic antibiotics, the anticipated rate of surgical site infection in a patient with a clean-contaminated wound like open cholecystectomy is 3%.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A newborn present with respiratory distress shortly after birth. An X-ray is performed, as depicted in the image below. Which condition is most likely demonstrated by these radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

This condition involves a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs such as bowel loops to herniate into the thoracic cavity, evident on the neonatal chest X-ray as shown in the image. It explains the respiratory distress due to lung compression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumomediastinum: Typically presents with air in the mediastinal space, which may appear as a continuous diaphragmatic line or air outlining the heart and major vessels, but does not include bowel loops in the thoracic cavity.

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: A chronic condition diagnosed with clinical features and a positive sweat test or genetic testing, typically not diagnosed via neonatal chest X-ray showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity.

 

Option D. Bronchiolitis: A respiratory condition common in infants, typically presenting with signs of infection and hyperinflated lungs on X-ray, not displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a critical neonatal condition that manifests with respiratory distress due to herniation of abdominal contents into the chest.
  • Early recognition through radiographic imaging is crucial for appropriate surgical intervention and management of respiratory support.

questions.text: During a summer event, a healthy 22-year-old man suddenly lost consciousness and subsequently drowned after jumping into a cold lake from a high cliff. Medical responders suspect a specific type of drowning related to the sudden exposure to cold water. What is the correct term for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immersion syndrome

 

  • Immersion syndrome (Hydrocution, submersion inhibition or cold water drowning): It refers to syncope resulting from cardiac dysrhythymias on sudden contact with water that is at least 5°C lower than body temperature.
  • Mechanism: Vagal stimulation leading to asystolic cardiac arrest (‘diving reflex’), or ventricular fibrillation secondary to QT prolongation after a massive release of catecholamine on contact with cold water

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wet drowning: This term describes a situation where water enters the lungs while submerged, leading to respiratory impairment, but it does not specifically relate to the shock caused by cold water.

 

Option C. Near drowning: This term refers to survivors of drowning incidents who still experience water inhalation that can lead to serious complications but does not specifically address the initial cold shock reaction.

 

Option D. Dry drowning: Dry drowning, a less commonly used and sometimes controversial term, refers to a situation where drowning occurs without water entering the lungs, often due to spasms in the airways. It's different from immersion syndrome, which is primarily a cardiac response to cold exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Immersion syndrome, also known as hydrocution, refers to a sudden cardiac arrest caused by the shock of cold water on the body.
  • This condition occurs when an individual enters cold water abruptly, causing a rapid change in heart rhythm that can lead to loss of consciousness and drowning if not immediately rescued. It is a reflex response, particularly affecting the cardiovascular system.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male, who underwent a kidney transplant due to renal failure, was prescribed a nucleotide derivative. Which nucleotide derivative is of therapeutic importance in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

  • Azathioprine is the correct answer as it is a nucleotide derivative widely used as an immunosuppressive drug in organ transplantation to prevent rejection.
  • Azathioprine works by inhibiting the proliferation of cells, particularly lymphocytes, which are crucial in the immune response.
  • By suppressing this aspect of the immune system, azathioprine helps to reduce the body's tendency to reject the newly transplanted organ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-Fluorouracil: 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a chemotherapy medication, primarily used to treat cancers by inhibiting DNA synthesis. It is not used as an immunosuppressant in organ transplantation.

 

Option B. Cytarabine: Cytarabine is another chemotherapy drug, used mainly to treat certain leukemias. It is not indicated for use in preventing organ rejection in transplant patients.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol is used primarily to treat gout and hyperuricemia (high levels of uric acid in the blood) by inhibiting xanthine oxidase, an enzyme involved in uric acid production. It does not have a role as an immunosuppressant in the context of organ transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Azathioprine is an immunosuppressive nucleotide derivative used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients due to its ability to inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.
  • This reduces the immune system's response against the transplanted organ, improving the chances of transplant success.

choices.text: Step up antibiotics

questions.text: A 25-year-old male following RTA is brought to casualty. Examination reveals bruising on left chest. Vitals are normal, O2 saturation is 98% without supplemental O2. Chest X ray shows fracture of left 4th/5th ribs, otherwise normal. Following admission, he complains of hemoptysis and his O2 levels start falling. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) O2 supplementation

 

  • The delayed drop in saturation and haemoptysis is suggestive of pulmonary contusion.
  • The natural progression of pulmonary contusion is worsening hypoxaemia for the first 24–48 hours.
  • Chest radiographic findings may be typically delayed. Contrast CT scanning can be confirmatory.
  • Haemoptysis or blood in the endotracheal tube is a sign of pulmonary contusion.
  • In mild contusion, the treatment is oxygen administration, pulmonary toilet and adequate analgesia. In more severe cases mechanical ventilation is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Step up antibiotics: Antibiotics may be given prophylactically but will not improve hypoxemia.

 

Option B. ICD insertion: ICD insertion is not indicated in contusion

 

Option C. CT thorax: CT thorax is diagnostic but will be done after stabilizing the drop in saturation.

 

Education Objective:

 

  • Worsening hypoxemia in a patient with rib fracture is likely to be related to pulmonary contusions.

choices.text: Superior pole of patella, impinging during flexion
Superior pole of patella, impinging during extension
Inferior pole of patella, impinging during flexion
Inferior pole of patella, impinging during extension

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the scar tissue in patellar clunk syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior pole of patella, impinging during extension

 

  • Patellar clunk syndrome is a condition that can occur postoperatively in patients who have undergone knee arthroplasty.
  • It involves the formation of a fibrous nodule or scar tissue at the superior pole of the patella.
  • The "clunk" phenomenon occurs when this nodule catches on the femoral component of the prosthesis during knee extension.
  • As the knee extends, the nodule moves over the anterior edge of the femoral component, producing a palpable and sometimes audible "clunk."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior pole of patella, impinging during flexion [18%]: Incorrect because the impingement typically occurs during knee extension, not flexion.

 

Option C. Inferior pole of patella, impinging during flexion [13%]: Incorrect as patellar clunk syndrome involves the superior, not inferior, pole of the patella.

 

Option D. Inferior pole of patella, impinging during extension: Also incorrect because, again, it is the superior pole of the patella involved in patellar clunk syndrome, not the inferior pole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patellar clunk syndrome, scar tissue forms at the superior pole of the patella and impinges, causing symptoms during the extension of the knee, not during flexion.

choices.text: High investment of tunica vaginalis

questions.text: A fourteen-year-old boy presents with right-sided acute scrotum. Examination reveals tenderness which worsens on lifting the testis. Which of these is the most common anatomical abnormality associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High investment of tunica vaginalis

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of testicular torsion.
  • Pain worsening on elevation of testis is seen in torsion, and used to differentiate it from acute epididymo-orchitis – Prehn’s sign.
  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis, causing the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Inverted testis: The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.

 

Option B. Loose epididymis: Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis, permitting torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Though many anatomical abnormalities lead to torsion, high investment of tunica vaginalis is the most common factor.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement.
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently true/correct statement.

questions.text:
Assertion: Anaphylactoid reaction can be caused by the first exposure.

 

Reason: Involves mast cell degranulation, without IgE activation.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.

 

  • The assertion is true because anaphylactoid reactions can indeed be caused by the first exposure to a substance.
  • These reactions mimic anaphylaxis but are not mediated by an immunologic allergen-specific IgE response.
  • Therefore, previous sensitization is not necessary.
  • The reason is also true; anaphylactoid reactions involve direct mast cell degranulation without the involvement of IgE antibodies.
  • However, this is not the correct explanation for why anaphylactoid reactions can occur on the first exposure.
  • The lack of necessity for prior sensitization is not due to the mechanism of mast cell degranulation but because the reaction is not mediated by an adaptive immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are defined as those reactions that produce the same clinical picture with anaphylaxis but are not IgE mediated, occur through a direct nonimmune-mediated release of mediators from mast cells and/or basophils or result from direct complement activation.
    • Prior sensitization by the antigen is not necessary
    • Most commonly caused by NSAIDs and radiocontrast media
    • It can occur on first exposure without IgE activation
    • Not hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A newborn is examined in the neonatal unit for multiple anomalies noted immediately after birth. The infant exhibits micrognathia, glossoptosis, and difficulties in breathing. The pediatrician also notes the infant's difficulty in feeding, which improves with positioning. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pierre Robin sequence

 

  • This condition is defined by a triad of micrognathia (small jaw), glossoptosis (downward displacement or retraction of the tongue), and airway obstruction.
  • These features lead to the feeding and breathing difficulties noted in the vignette.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: Typically presents with features like hypotonia, slanted palpebral fissures, a single transverse palmar crease, and intellectual disability, which may not be immediately evident but are distinct from Pierre Robin sequence characteristics.

 

Option B. Treacher Collins syndrome: Characterized by craniofacial deformities including underdeveloped zygoma, lower eyelid colobomas, and ear anomalies. Although some features may overlap, such as feeding difficulties, it lacks the specific trio of Pierre Robin sequence: micrognathia, glossoptosis, and airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Cleft palate: While it can be associated with feeding problems and is sometimes a part of the Pierre Robin sequence, it does not typically include the trio of micrognathia, glossoptosis, and airway obstruction unless it is specifically part of a broader syndrome like Pierre Robin.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pierre Robin sequence involves a characteristic triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis, and airway obstruction, often complicating feeding and breathing in newborns.
  • Early recognition is vital to manage airway and feeding issues effectively and to plan for potential surgical interventions.
  • Multidisciplinary management including neonatology, pediatric surgery, and possibly genetics is often necessary for these patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine eye examination. During the visit, the ophthalmologist decides to measure the patient’s intraocular pressure (IOP) due to his high risk of glaucoma. The instrument used is as below. Which type of tonometer is being utilized in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schiotz tonometer

 

  • The Schiotz tonometer is a traditional device used for measuring intraocular pressure based on the indentation technique.
  • It requires the patient to be in a supine position as it uses the weight of the instrument itself placed on the cornea to indent it and measure the IOP indirectly.
  • This method is less commonly used today but is notable for its historical significance and utility in certain clinical settings where other tonometers are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perkins applanation tonometer: The Perkins applanation tonometer is a portable version of the Goldmann tonometer, used for measuring IOP and suitable for use when patients cannot be positioned at a slit lamp.

 

Option C. Goldmann tonometer: The Goldmann tonometer is considered the gold standard for IOP measurement and utilizes the applanation method, requiring the patient to be seated at a slit lamp.

 

Option D. Non-contact tonometer: Non-contact tonometer, or "air puff" tonometer, measures IOP by delivering a rapid air pulse to the cornea and does not require contact with the eye, hence the name.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the different types of tonometers and their operating principles is crucial for accurate assessment of intraocular pressure, a key factor in diagnosing and managing glaucoma.
  • The Schiotz tonometer, while older, is characterized by its use of the indentation method and requirement for a supine patient position.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents to the emergency department with complaints of watery diarrhea and abdominal cramping. He was recently treated with antibiotics for a respiratory tract infection. A stool test is positive for Clostridium difficile toxin. Given the patient's recent antibiotic use, which class of antibiotics is most commonly associated with the development of Clostridium difficile diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoroquinolones

 

  • Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is often associated with prior antibiotic use, which disrupts the normal intestinal flora.
  • Among the antibiotics listed, fluoroquinolones have been increasingly implicated in CDI, especially with the rise of fluoroquinolone-resistant C. difficile strains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminopenicillins: These can also predispose to C. difficile infection, but there has been a particular increase in CDI associated with fluoroquinolones in recent outbreaks.

 

Option C. Macrolides: While these antibiotics can disrupt the gut flora and may lead to diarrhea, they are less commonly associated with C. difficile compared to fluoroquinolones.

 

Option D. Carbapenems: These broad-spectrum antibiotics are also a risk factor for C. difficile infection, but recent data suggests a stronger association with fluoroquinolones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prolonged antimicrobial use is the most important risk factor for Clostridium difficile diarrhea as this can result in disruption of the normal colonic flora, which enhances the susceptibility to C. difficile infection.
  • Cephalosporins (e.g. ceftriaxone) are frequently responsible for this condition
  • Other antibiotics, such as clindamycin, ampicillin and fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) are also implicated in hospital outbreaks
  • However, all antibiotics, including vancomycin and metronidazole (which are the drugs of choice in C. difficile infection) have been found to carry a risk of infection, if given for prolonged duration.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents who are concerned about the apparent larger size of his eyes compared to other children his age. On examination, the pediatrician notes the child's eyes as seen in the picture below. No other abnormalities are noted on physical examination. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buphthalmos

 

  • Buphthalmos, also known as "ox eye," is a condition typically associated with congenital glaucoma.
  • It is characterized by an enlargement of the eyeball due to increased intraocular pressure in children.
  • The increased pressure causes the eye to stretch and enlarge, which can also lead to corneal haziness due to corneal edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratoconus: Keratoconus involves a progressive thinning and conical deformation of the cornea but does not cause an overall enlargement of the eyeball.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Orbital cellulitis is an infection characterized by pain, eyelid erythema, fever, and impaired eye movement, rather than enlargement of the eyeball itself.

 

Option D. Marfan syndrome: Marfan syndrome can involve eye symptoms, typically lens dislocation, but does not lead to an enlargement of the eyeball itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Buphthalmos is a critical sign of congenital glaucoma in children and requires immediate referral to an ophthalmologist for management to prevent permanent visual impairment.

questions.text: A 22-year-old boy was involved in an argument but quickly worsened into a street brawl with the use of knives. He was examined in the emergency department and found to have a bleeding stab wound in his left flank. A urine specimen revealed frank blood. Of the organs listed below, which one is least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The inferior vena cava (IVC) is least likely to be injured in this scenario. Given the location of the stab wound in the left flank and the presence of hematuria (blood in urine), the organs located on the left side of the body are more prone to injury.
  • The spleen, left suprarenal (adrenal) gland, and stomach are all located on the left side and can be affected by a penetrating injury in the left flank.
  • The inferior vena cava, however, is located more to the right side of the body and would be less likely to be injured by a stab wound to the left flank.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: The spleen is located in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen and could easily be injured in a left flank stabbing incident.

 

Option B. Left suprarenal gland: The left suprarenal gland, situated on top of the left kidney, is also a plausible structure to be injured in a left flank stabbing.

 

Option C. Stomach: The stomach is an organ that extends across the upper abdomen, and part of it lies in the left upper quadrant, making it susceptible to injury in a stabbing incident to the left flank.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IVC is positioned more to the right which allows clinicians to consider other organs on the left side as more likely to be affected in a left-flank trauma scenario.

choices.text: To evaluate for carpal tunnel syndrome
To assess for thoracic outlet syndrome
To determine the presence of De Quervain's tenosynovitis
To check for patency of radial and ulnar arteries

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with numbness and tingling in her right hand, especially during overhead activities. Adson’s test is performed. What is the primary objective of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To assess for thoracic outlet syndrome

 

  • Adson's test is used to assess for Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), which occurs when the blood vessels or nerves between the thoracic outlet are compressed, leading to symptoms like those described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To evaluate for Carpal tunnel syndrome: Typically assessed using Tinel's sign (tapping over the median nerve at the wrist) or Phalen's maneuver (flexing the wrists and pressing the backs of the hands together).
