Option C. To determine the presence of De Quervain's tenosynovitis: Finkelstein's test is used, where the patient makes a fist with the fingers over the thumb and then ulnar deviates the wrist, eliciting pain if positive.

 

Option D. To check for patency of radial and ulnar arteries: The Allen’s test is performed for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adson's test is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome, a condition that can be aggravated by certain postures or activities that involve repetitive arm or shoulder movements.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with symptoms of malabsorption and iron deficiency anemia. A duodenal biopsy reveals complete villous atrophy. Which of the following is safe?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rice

 

  • Complete villous atrophy observed in a duodenal biopsy is a hallmark finding in celiac disease, which is an autoimmune disorder triggered by ingestion of gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Rice, however, is a gluten-free grain and is safe for consumption by individuals with celiac disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wheat: Contains gluten, which is the main trigger for celiac disease symptoms and villous atrophy.

 

Option C. Oats: While oats are inherently gluten-free, they are often contaminated with gluten unless specifically labelled as gluten-free. Moreover, some celiac patients may react to avenin, a protein in oats similar to gluten.

 

Option D. Barley: Contains gluten and is unsafe for individuals with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For individuals diagnosed with celiac disease, as indicated by symptoms of malabsorption, iron deficiency anemia, and duodenal biopsy showing complete villous atrophy, safe dietary choices should exclude any sources of gluten. Rice is a safe, gluten-free option for these patients.

questions.text: In the examination of stool samples under a microscope, an egg is observed that contains three pairs of hooklets and polar filaments. Notably, this egg does not stain with bile. Based on these characteristics, identify the egg from the following options:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hymenolepis nana

 

  • Hymenolepis nana, also known as the dwarf tapeworm, produces eggs that are characteristic with the presence of an oncosphere that has hooklets and polar filaments, which are useful for attaching to the intestinal wall.
  • These eggs do not stain with bile, which helps in distinguishing them from similar parasitic eggs.

 

 

Non-bile stained egg of Hymenolepis nana - A. saline mount-three pairs of hooklets are seen clearly; B. iodine mount- polar filaments are seen clearly

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Taenia solium and c. Taenia saginata: The eggs of both Taenia species do not typically feature polar filaments and their oncospheres contain hooklets but differ in the specifics and bile staining properties discussed.

 

Option D. Diphyllobothrium latum: The eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum are operculated and do not contain hooklets or polar filaments, making them distinct from the description provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

H. nana eggs –

 

  • Eggs are the infective form as well as diagnostic form of the parasite.
  • Egg is round to slightly oval, 30–47μm size, Nonbile stained (colorless in saline mount)
  • It has two membranes and an oncosphere with six Hooklets
  • Polar filaments: 4–8 polar filaments emerge from poles and lie between the two membranes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male transplant patient on immunosuppressive therapy is scheduled for routine follow-up. Considering the potential side effects of his medications, which of the following drugs specifically necessitates regular monitoring of renal function due to its nephrotoxic potential?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cyclosporine A

 

  • Cyclosporine A is a calcineurin inhibitor used in transplant patients to prevent organ rejection.
  • It is known for its nephrotoxic effects, which can lead to both acute and chronic kidney damage.
  • Regular monitoring of renal function is essential to prevent and manage potential nephrotoxicity, making adjustments to dosing as necessary based on kidney function tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: This medication is more commonly associated with hepatotoxicity and bone marrow suppression; hence, liver function tests and complete blood count are more routinely monitored.

 

Option B. Mycophenolate mofetil: Known primarily for its gastrointestinal side effects and bone marrow suppression, it requires monitoring for hematologic changes rather than renal function.

 

Option C. Azathioprine: While it can affect the liver and blood cells, azathioprine is less commonly associated with direct nephrotoxic effects compared to cyclosporine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cyclosporine A due to its significant nephrotoxic potential, can lead to both acute and chronic renal impairment.

questions.text:
A health policy analyst is evaluating the Human Development Index (HDI) for a Southeast Asian country to aid in policy formulation. The following data is available for the country:

 

  • Life expectancy at birth: 74 years
  • Mean years of schooling: 13 years
  • Gross National Income (GNI) per capita: $40,000 (international dollars)

 

Calculate the HDI for this country.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.73

 

To calculate the HDI, each of the three dimensions is indexed between 0 and 1 using the formula:

 

Calculation of each dimension index =      Actual value - Minimum value

 Maximum value - Minimum value

 

  • HDI is Geometric mean of 3 dimension indices =  ILife1/3 × IEducation1/3 × IIncome1/3

 

Calculation –

 

Assuming the necessary minimum and maximum values for normalizing the indexes are:

 

  • Life expectancy: 20 years (minimum), 85 years (maximum)
  • Schooling: 0 years (minimum), 15 years (maximum)
  • GNI per capita: $100 (minimum), $75,000 (maximum)

 

 

Thus, the HDI for the country is approximately - 0.73

 

Educational objective

 

  • HDI is a composite index comprising of 3 dimensions: Knowledge; Income and Longevity
  • India - Human Development Index (HDI): 0.633 (Rank 132 - Medium Development, 2021–22)

questions.text: Which of the following snakes is NOT typically covered by the standard polyvalent snake antivenoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ophiophagus hannah (King Cobra)

 

  • Polyvalent snake antivenoms are generally formulated to neutralize the venom of the most common and medically significant snakes in a particular region.
  • While Naja naja, Daboia russellii, and Bungarus caeruleus are commonly included in these antivenoms in areas where these species are prevalent, Ophiophagus hannah (King Cobra) is often not included.
  • The venom of the King Cobra is unique and requires a specific antivenom due to its different toxin components and the severity of its effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naja naja (Indian Cobra): Typically included in polyvalent antivenoms in regions where it is found due to its frequent interactions with humans and potent neurotoxic venom.

 

Option C. Daboia russellii (Russell's Viper): Included because of its highly hemotoxic venom which poses significant medical risks.

 

Option D. Bungarus caeruleus (Common Krait): Included in polyvalent antivenoms due to its potent neurotoxic venom and prevalence in populated areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lyophilized polyvalent antisnake venom (ASV) serum available in India is effective against common poisonous snakes (cobra, common krait, saw scaled viper and Russell’s viper).
  • The recommended initial dose of ASV is 8–10 vials, administered via IV route over a period of 1 hr.
  • Repeat doses for vasculotoxic species is based on the 6 hr rule (depending on the coagulation profile); maximum recommended dose is 30 vials.
  • Repeat doses for neurotoxic is based on the 1–2 hr rule (depending on whether patients have not improved, or worsened); maximum dose is 20 vials.

choices.text: Submental endotracheal intubation

questions.text: A construction worker met with an accident and presented to the trauma centre when a heavy concrete block fell over his face. He was found to have severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injury. He was not able to open his mouth and, on examination, he is found to have multiple fractures and obstruction in nasopharynx as well as oropharynx. In order to maintain a patent airway, the following procedure was done for him. Which of the following options define the procedure correctly?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroidotomy 

 

Cricothyroidotomy involves making an incision through the skin and cricothyroid membrane to establish a patent airway during certain life-threatening situations, such as airway obstruction by a foreign body or massive facial trauma. It is quicker and easier to perform than tracheostomy and does not require manipulation of the cervical spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submental endotracheal intubation: Incorrect - Submental endotracheal intubation is not the correct procedure for establishing a patent airway in cases of severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injury. It involves passing an endotracheal tube through a surgical incision made in the submental region and into the trachea.

 

Option B. Emergency tracheostomy: Incorrect - Emergency tracheostomy is not the correct procedure described in the scenario. It involves making an incision directly into the trachea below the cricoid cartilage to establish a patent airway in cases of upper airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous tracheostomy: Incorrect - Subcutaneous tracheostomy is not the procedure described in the scenario. It involves creating a stoma in the neck below the cricoid cartilage for long-term mechanical ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injury with airway obstruction, cricothyroidotomy (cricothyrotomy) is a rapid and effective procedure to establish a patent airway, especially when orotracheal or nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated or difficult.

choices.text: Hypothermia is defined as an axillary temperature of less than 36.5 °C.
Cold stress in adults is classified by an axillary temperature ranging from 36.0 to 36.4 °C.
Severe hypothermia is characterized by an axillary temperature of less than 32 °C.
Hyperthermia is defined as an axillary temperature greater than 36.5 °C.

questions.text: Review the statements regarding temperature classifications in a clinical setting. Which statement is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperthermia is defined as an axillary temperature greater than 36.5 °C.

 

  • False. Hyperthermia is defined as an axillary temperature greater than 37.5 °C, not 36.5 °C.

 

Option A. Hypothermia is defined as an axillary temperature of less than 36.5 °C: True. Hypothermia is clinically defined as having a body temperature less than 36.5 °C.

 

 Option B. Cold stress in adults is classified by an axillary temperature ranging from 36.0 to 36.4 °C: True, though it's more commonly applied to neonates. In adults, "cold stress" is not typically used to describe slight drops in temperature and is more often associated with environmental factors.

 

Option C. Severe hypothermia is characterized by an axillary temperature of less than 32 °C: True. Severe hypothermia occurs when the body temperature falls below 32 °C, which is a critical medical condition requiring immediate intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperthermia is defined as axillary temperature > 37.5 degree Celsius.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not result in theophylline toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amoxicillin

 

  • Amoxicillin does not interact with theophylline in a manner that results in increased levels of theophylline or enhances its toxicity.
  • Theophylline is metabolized by the liver, and certain medications can inhibit this metabolism, leading to higher serum levels and potential toxicity.
  • Amoxicillin, a penicillin antibiotic, does not affect theophylline metabolism and is safe to use concurrently without the risk of increasing theophylline blood concentrations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: This fluoroquinolone antibiotic can inhibit the metabolism of theophylline, leading to increased levels of theophylline in the blood and potential toxicity.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: As a macrolide antibiotic, erythromycin can inhibit cytochrome P450 enzymes involved in theophylline metabolism, thus increasing the risk of theophylline toxicity.

 

Option D. Cimetidine: This H2 receptor antagonist is known to inhibit the metabolism of theophylline as well, potentially leading to elevated theophylline levels and increased toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Certain antibiotics like ciprofloxacin and erythromycin, as well as medications like cimetidine, can increase the risk of theophylline toxicity by inhibiting its metabolism, amoxicillin does not affect theophylline levels and is safe for use with this medication.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with chronic cough, chest pain, and weight loss. Imaging reveals pulmonary nodules, and a biopsy is taken. Considering the epidemiology of deep mycoses in India, which of the following is the most common cause of systemic fungal infection in this patient's demographic?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histoplasmosis

 

  • Histoplasmosis, caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, is reported to be the most common systemic mycosis in India.
  • It is endemic in certain areas and is usually acquired through inhalation of airborne conidia from bird or bat droppings.
  • Patients can present with a range of symptoms, from mild flu-like illness to severe disseminated disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomycosis: This is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis and is endemic to North America, particularly the southeastern and south-central states, near waterways and in wooded areas, not commonly reported in India.

 

Option C. Coccidiomycosis: Also known as "valley fever," it is caused by Coccidioides spp. and is endemic to the southwestern United States, northern Mexico, and parts of Central and South America, not India.

 

Option D. Cryptococcosis: Caused by Cryptococcus spp., this fungal infection does occur in India but is not as common as histoplasmosis. Cryptococcosis typically affects immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Deep mycoses are not prevalent in India, however, among them Histoplasma is more common.
  • Examples of deep mycoses—Histoplasmosis, Blastomycosis, Coccidiomycosis and paracoccidiomycosis

questions.text: In the context of hospital management and the efficient use of healthcare services, the bed turnover interval is a critical metric. For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, should the bed turnover interval always be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Slightly positive

 

  • Bed turn over interval: Amount of time beds at hospital are unoccupied until next patients’ admission following a patients’ discharge
    • Negative values: Indicate over 100% occupancy, scarcity of beds, over-utilization of services
    • Positive values: Indicate vacant beds, underutilization of services due to defective admission process or poor quality medical care
    • Slight positive values: Indicate optimum utilization of services

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Largely positive: This would indicate inefficiency, with beds remaining empty for longer than desired.

 

Option C. Slightly negative: This scenario is not usually possible as beds cannot be occupied by more than one patient at a time.

 

Option D. Largely negative: This would be highly impractical and indicative of significant issues in hospital management and patient flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The bed turnover interval should ideally be slightly positive, which reflects a balance between efficient bed usage and providing adequate time for bed preparation between patients, thereby optimizing hospital resource utilization.

questions.text: A 34-week pregnant woman with hypertension presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and the absence of fetal movements. On examination, her uterus is contracted with increased tone, and fetal heart sounds are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abruptio placenta

 

  • The clinical presentation of pain in the abdomen, vaginal bleeding, increased uterine tone, and absent fetal heart sounds in a hypertensive pregnant woman strongly suggests abruptio placenta.
  • This condition involves the premature separation of a normally implanted placenta from the uterus, which can lead to fetal distress or demise, significant maternal pain, and potentially life-threatening complications such as hemorrhage.
  • The presence of hypertension increases the risk for this condition.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Placenta previa: Typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding and would not generally cause increased uterine tone or fetal demise.

 

Option B. Hydramnios: Characterized by an excessive volume of amniotic fluid and may lead to discomfort and complications, but it does not typically present with acute pain and bleeding.

 

Option C. Premature labour: While it can include premature contractions and possibly some bleeding, the symptoms described are more severe and acute than those usually associated with premature labor alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In abruptio placenta, especially in hypertensive patients, as this condition necessitates immediate medical intervention due to the high risk to both mother and fetus.

questions.text: A 47-year-old hypertensive patient was on metoprolol treatment, and verapamil was added to the therapy. This combination can result in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bradycardia with AV block

 

  • Adding verapamil, a calcium channel blocker, to a regimen that includes metoprolol, a beta-blocker, significantly increases the risk of bradycardia and atrioventricular (AV) block.
  • Both drugs decrease heart rate and myocardial contractility.
  • Verapamil, in particular, has strong effects on the AV node, slowing conduction and potentially leading to various degrees of heart block.
  • The combined effect of these two drugs on heart rate and AV nodal conduction can lead to pronounced bradycardia and higher degrees of AV block.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tachycardia: This outcome is unlikely as both metoprolol and verapamil typically slow heart rate.

 

Option B. Torsades de pointes: Neither metoprolol nor verapamil are associated with a significant risk of causing Torsades de pointes, which is typically related to drugs that prolong the QT interval.

 

Option C. Atrial fibrillation: While both drugs can affect atrial electrophysiology, their primary action reducing sympathetic tone generally helps in controlling rather than inducing atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of metoprolol and verapamil can lead to an increased risk of bradycardia and AV block due to their additive effects on heart rate reduction and AV nodal conduction slowing.
  • This drug interaction necessitates careful monitoring of cardiac function when these medications are used together.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions is most likely NOT X-linked?

 

  1. Wilson’s disease
  2. Hemophilia
  3. Thalassemia
  4. G6PD deficiency
  5. ABO blood groups system
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 5

 

Explanation:

 

1. Wilson’s Disease: Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13, leading to excessive copper accumulation in tissues. This condition is not X-linked but rather follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

 

3. Thalassemia: Thalassemia is a group of inherited hemoglobin disorders caused by mutations in the genes for the alpha and beta globin chains of hemoglobin. The genes involved are located on chromosomes 11 and 16, respectively, thus they are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, not X-linked.

 

5. ABO Blood Group System: The ABO blood group system is determined by the ABO gene located on chromosome 9. The inheritance of blood groups is based on codominance and is not associated with X or Y chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Hemophilia: Hemophilia A and B are inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. The genes for factors VIII and IX involved in clotting are located on the X chromosome. In families with a history of these diseases, males are predominantly affected, and females are usually carriers.

 

4. G6PD Deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is also an X-linked recessive disorder. The G6PD gene is located on the X chromosome. This disorder can lead to episodic hemolytic anemia triggered by certain infections, drugs, or foods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statement(s) about pediatric surgical principles in contrast to adults:

 

  1. Wider abdomen with reduced vertical distance
  2. The bladder is mainly intra-peritoneal
  3. Ribs are more horizontal and rigid
  4. Umbilicus is lower than an adult
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 3 is incorrect

 

Option 1. Wider abdomen with shallow pelvis: horizontal incisions are preferred in children→ EXPOSURE is better

 

Option 2. The bladder is mainly intra-peritoneal: Bladder is intra-peritoneal; liver extends sub-costally→ Easily traumatized in children following blunt trauma

 

Option 3. Ribs are more horizontal and rigid: Flexible ribs in children which done easily fracture→ If fractures→ Sign of child abuse

 

Option 4. Umbilicus is lower than an adult: Lower umbilicus→Difficulty in stoma position in the lower abdomen

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pediatric surgical principles vary from adult due to differential anatomical correlates.

choices.text: Cord prolapse of the second baby
Inadvertent use of IV ergometrine with the delivery of the anterior shoulder of the first baby
Breech presentation of the second baby

questions.text: In a twin pregnancy, several situations may necessitate the urgent delivery of the second twin. Which of the following is not an indication for the urgent delivery of the second baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Breech presentation of the second baby

 

  • Breech presentation of the second twin is not, by itself, an indication for urgent delivery.
  • Many breech second twins are safely delivered vaginally, especially if the first twin has been delivered vaginally without complications.
  • The decision to deliver urgently due to breech presentation depends on other factors such as fetal distress or complications during labor, but breech presentation alone does not typically necessitate immediate delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placentae: This is a critical condition where the placenta detaches prematurely, which can compromise the oxygen and nutrient supply to the second twin, necessitating urgent delivery.

 

Option B. Cord prolapse of the second baby: This is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord descends through the cervix into the vaginal canal before the baby, posing a risk of compression and necessitating immediate delivery.

 

Option C. Inadvertent use of IV ergometrine with the delivery of the anterior shoulder of the first baby: Ergometrine can cause uterine hyperstimulation, potentially compromising the uteroplacental blood flow to the second twin, which could necessitate urgent delivery to prevent fetal distress or worse outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • It is critical to differentiate between clinical situations that require immediate intervention from those that may allow for a more measured approach.
  • Understanding these distinctions helps in managing twin pregnancies effectively, reducing risks to both the mother and the infants.

questions.text: During a routine check of the anesthesia machine before surgery, a resident is tasked with ensuring that the carbon dioxide (CO2) absorber is fully functional to prevent the rebreathing of exhaled gases. Which component is primarily responsible for absorbing CO2 in the anesthesia circuit?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcium hydroxide

 

  • Calcium hydroxide is the main component of most modern CO2 absorbers used in anesthesia machines.
  • It chemically reacts with carbon dioxide to form calcium carbonate, thereby effectively removing CO2 from the circulating gases in the closed anesthesia system.
  • This process is crucial for maintaining a clean and safe breathing environment for the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium bicarbonate: Sodium  bicarbonate is not typically used as a CO2 absorber in anesthesia systems. It is more commonly used as an antacid or in metabolic acidosis treatment.

 

Option C. Sodium hydroxide: Sodium hydroxide may be present in some CO2 absorbent formulations, but it is not the primary active ingredient. Its role is more auxiliary, enhancing the efficiency of the primary absorbent.

 

Option D. Magnesium oxide: Magnesium oxide is not used in CO2 absorption for anesthesia machines; it has different industrial and medical applications, such as a laxative or an antacid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the function and composition of the CO2 absorber in anesthesia machines is essential for anesthesia providers.
  • Proper maintenance and regular replacement of the absorbent material are crucial to prevent the accumulation of carbon dioxide in the system, ensuring the safety and effectiveness of mechanical ventilation during anesthesia.

questions.text:
Match the following national institutes with their correct locations:

 

Institutes:

  1. National Institute of Occupational Health (NIOH)
  2. National Tuberculosis Institute (NTI)
  3. National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI)
  4. National Institute of Epidemiology (NIE)

 

Locations:

  1. Chennai
  2. Bengaluru
  3. Nagpur
  4. Ahmedabad
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

Explanation:

 

  1. National Institute of Occupational Health (NIOH) is located in Ahmedabad and focuses on occupational health research and policies in India.
  2. National Tuberculosis Institute (NTI) in Bengaluru is involved in tuberculosis research, control, and training.
  3. National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI) in Nagpur specializes in environmental science research and solutions to environmental problems.
  4. National Institute of Epidemiology (NIE) in Chennai conducts research in epidemiology, a crucial field in public health for tracking diseases and health patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presented with severe shortness of breath and on examination the emergency physician observes a significant decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. Which of the following conditions is most characteristically associated with this picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac tamponade

 

  • Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, which exerts pressure on the heart and impairs its ability to pump effectively.
  • One of the hallmark signs of cardiac tamponade is pulsus paradoxus, a significant decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.
  • This occurs because the heart is compressed by the accumulated fluid, especially during the respiratory cycle when the heart normally would expand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: While constrictive pericarditis also involves the pericardium, it is characterized by thickening or calcification of the pericardial layers, not fluid accumulation. It does not typically present with pulsus paradoxus but rather with signs of heart failure and Kussmaul's sign (increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration).


Option C. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy: This condition involves abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, particularly the septum, which obstructs blood flow but does not typically involve changes in blood pressure with respiration. It is more associated with symptoms like chest pain and syncope rather than respiratory-related blood pressure changes.


Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This affects the myocardium's ability to stretch and fill but does not typically cause changes in blood pressure with respiration. It leads to symptoms of heart failure due to poor filling and decreased cardiac output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The significant decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, known as pulsus paradoxus, is most characteristically associated with cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: During a routine cataract surgery workshop, a medical student is asked to identify the instrument show in the picture below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacoemulsification handpiece

 

  • The phacoemulsification handpiece is the essential instrument used in modern cataract surgery.
  • It uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the cataractous lens, allowing for its removal through a small incision, which facilitates quicker recovery and reduces the risks associated with larger incisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitrectomy probe: This instrument is used primarily in vitreoretinal surgery to remove vitreous gel or to perform delicate retinal manipulations, not typically involved in cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Retinal cryoprobe: Utilized in retinal surgeries to treat retinal tears or detachments through cryotherapy, where extreme cold is used to create an adhesive scar, again not related to cataract extraction.

 

Option B. Capsulorhexis forceps: While these are used in cataract surgery, they are specifically designed for creating a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis to open the lens capsule, not for lens emulsification itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The phacoemulsification handpiece is central to modern cataract surgery, enabling efficient lens removal and minimal postoperative recovery time.

questions.text: Dr. Ahmed is exploring various techniques to enhance team productivity in his healthcare facility. He seeks methods grounded in behavioral sciences to understand and modify team behaviors to achieve specific organizational goals. Which of the following techniques is based primarily on behavioral sciences methods and is best suited for his needs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Management by objectives

 

  • Management by Objectives (MBO) is an appropriate technique because it integrates the principles of behavioral sciences by involving employees in goal setting, which aligns their individual performances with organizational objectives.
  • The process fosters commitment and motivation, as employees take part in creating meaningful objectives and understand how their behaviors directly impact the broader goals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Network analysis: Network analysis primarily examines the interconnections within a network, focusing more on relational and structural dynamics rather than behavioral changes.

 

Option C. Systems analysis: Systems analysis deals with the examination and evaluation of the various components of a system and their interactions, which is more related to technical and operational processes.

 

Option D. Decision making: Decision making involves choosing among alternatives and is a broader cognitive process used in various disciplines, not specifically a technique based on behavioral sciences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Behavioural sciences methods include Organizational design, Personal management, Communication, Information system.
  • Management by Objectives (MBO)
  • Quantitative methods include Cost benefit analysis, Cost effective analysis, Cost accounting, Input-output analysis, Model, Systems analysis, Network analysis (PERT/ CPM), Planning programming budget system, Work sampling, Decision making

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence for the Thomas test:

 

  1. Squaring of pelvis
  2. Flexion of the hip
  3. Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis
  4. Measure actual flexion deformity
  5. Ensure that ischial tuberosity touches the ground
  6. Monitor for overcorrection of the normal side
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3,2,6,5,4

 

  • The Thomas test is used to assess for hip flexion deformity. The correct sequence for performing the Thomas test is as follows:
    • 3. Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis: The test starts with the patient lying flat on their back. The clinician observes the natural curve of the lumbar spine to establish a baseline for lumbar lordosis.
    • 2. Flexion of the hip: The patient then flexes one hip, bringing the knee towards the chest, which should flatten the lumbar spine against the examination table. This maneuver helps to stabilize the pelvis and isolate the movement of the hip being tested.
    • 6. Monitor for overcorrection of the normal side: As the patient flexes the unaffected hip, the clinician must ensure that the opposite, or “normal” side, does not overcorrect or lift, as this could give a false impression of the flexibility or contracture of the affected hip.
    • 5. Ensure that ischial tuberosity touches the ground: The ischial tuberosity of the flexed hip should remain in contact with the table to ensure that any apparent hip flexion is true flexion and not a tilting of the pelvis.
    • 4. Measure actual flexion deformity: Finally, the clinician assesses the degree of hip flexion deformity by measuring the angle between the thigh and the examination table. If the thigh lifts off the table, this indicates a hip flexion deformity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1,2,3,4,5: Incorrect because the sequence does not start with observing the lumbar lordosis, which is essential before the flexion of the hip.

 

Option B. 3,2,1,4,6: Incorrect because it does not include ensuring that the ischial tuberosity touches the ground before measuring the actual flexion deformity.

 

Option D. 3,6,2,5,4: Incorrect because the sequence should include monitoring for overcorrection after ensuring the ischial tuberosity touches the ground.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the Thomas test, the sequence begins with assessing the lumbar lordosis before hip flexion, followed by monitoring for overcorrection of the normal side, ensuring the ischial tuberosity remains in contact with the examination table, and finally measuring the actual hip flexion deformity.

choices.text: Centromedian, Ventral Anterior, Ventral Lateral Nuclei
Mediodorsal, VPL and VPM Nuclei
Ventral Anterior, Ventral lateral, Anterior Nuclei
Ventral Lateral, Anterior, Dorsal Medial Nuclei

questions.text: Which group of thalamic nuclei receives projections from the globus pallidus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centromedian, Ventral Anterior, Ventral Lateral Nuclei

 

The Globus pallidus projects to three thalamic nuclei – Centro-median, ventral anterior and ventral lateral nuclei

 

  • The Centromedian nucleus is involved in motor functions and arousal,
  • The ventral anterior (VA) and ventral lateral (VL) nuclei are key recipients of projections from the globus pallidus and are involved in motor control.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mediodorsal, VPL (Ventral Posterolateral), and VPM (Ventral Posteromedial) Nuclei: The mediodorsal nucleus is primarily associated with limbic functions, while the VPL and VPM are primarily involved in sensory processing. These nuclei are not the primary targets of projections from the globus pallidus.

 

Option C. Ventral Anterior, Ventral Lateral, Anterior Nuclei: The ventral anterior and ventral lateral nuclei are correct as they receive projections from the globus pallidus. However, the anterior nuclei of the thalamus are mainly involved in limbic functions and do not primarily receive input from the globus pallidus.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral, Anterior, Dorsal Medial Nuclei: The ventral lateral nucleus, the anterior and dorsal medial nuclei is involved in motor functions and does receive projections from the globus pallidus. The dorsal medial nucleus is more involved in cognitive and emotional functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Centromedian, Ventral Anterior, Ventral Lateral Nuclei: The centromedian nucleus is involved in motor functions and arousal, the ventral anterior (VA) and ventral lateral (VL) nuclei are key recipients of projections from the globus pallidus and are involved in motor control.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has a routine health check-up. She has a normal BMI of 22, a fasting plasma glucose level of 120 mg/dL, and her urinalysis shows mild glucosuria without ketonuria or proteinuria. She has no insulin autoantibodies, and her father experienced similar symptoms at 20 years old. Which gene mutation is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucokinase

 

  • The findings suggest a diagnosis of Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY), a form of diabetes typically caused by a single gene mutation leading to dysfunction in insulin production or secretion.
  • Given the hereditary pattern and the presence of mild hyperglycemia without autoantibodies, a glucokinase mutation is most likely.
  • Glucokinase acts as the glucose sensor for the beta cell and a mutation here would lead to a higher threshold for insulin secretion in response to glucose, causing mild hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucagon: A mutation in the gene encoding glucagon would typically affect glucose mobilization from the liver but is not typically associated with the presentation of stable, mild hyperglycemia that has a familial pattern, as seen in MODY.

 

Option C. GLUT4 - GLUT4 is a glucose transporter protein whose expression is insulin-dependent and found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscle. Mutations in GLUT4 can lead to conditions like insulin resistance, but not typically the MODY profile, which involves an issue with insulin secretion rather than action.

 

Option D. Insulin: While mutations in the insulin gene can cause diabetes, such as in neonatal diabetes, the presentation of this condition is usually more severe than the mild hyperglycemia described in the question. Moreover, it would not cause glucosuria in the absence of more pronounced hyperglycemia or insulin autoantibodies as seen in autoimmune diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When encountering a case of mild, stable, fasting hyperglycemia that is familial and presents without insulin autoantibodies, consider a glucokinase gene mutation, which is one of the causes of Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY).

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with aggressive behavior and poor concentration is brought with presenting complaints of joint pain and reduced urinary output. Mother gives history of self-mutilation of his finger. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HGPRTase.

 

  • The child's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is characterized by hyperuricemia, neurological dysfunction, and self-mutilating behaviors.
  • The syndrome is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRTase), which is important in the purine salvage pathway.
  • The lack of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of uric acid and the associated symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenosine deaminase: Deficiency of adenosine deaminase is typically associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) rather than the symptoms described.

 

Option C. APRTase: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRTase) deficiency can lead to kidney stones or crystalluria, but it does not cause the neurological or behavioral symptoms mentioned.

 

Option D. Acid maltase: Acid maltase deficiency, also known as Pompe disease, is a glycogen storage disease characterized by muscle weakness and respiratory problems, not by self-mutilation or the other symptoms listed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HGPRTase deficiency is associated with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, leading to excessive uric acid production, neurological abnormalities, and self-mutilating behaviors.
  • It's crucial for medical professionals to recognize the enzymatic and clinical aspects of this genetic disorder for proper diagnosis and management.

questions.text: In the management of ocular conditions, which of the following medications should be avoided in patients with a known allergy to sulfonamides due to potential cross-reactivity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brinzolamide

 

  • Brinzolamide is an inhibitor of carbonic anhydrase and is structurally a sulfonamide.
  • Sulfonamides can cause hypersensitivity reactions in susceptible individuals, and this cross-reactivity is significant in patients with a known sulfonamide allergy.
  • Therefore, Brinzolamide should be avoided in these patients as it may induce similar allergic reactions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Levobunolol: This is a beta-blocker used in the treatment of glaucoma. It does not have a sulfonamide structure and is thus safe for use in patients allergic to sulfonamides.

 

Option B. Bimatoprost: This medication is a prostaglandin analogue used for reducing intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients. It is not related to sulfonamides and does not pose a risk of cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Brimonidine: As an alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist, this drug is also used in managing glaucoma. It lacks any sulfonamide structure, making it safe for sulfonamide-allergic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brinzolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, should be avoided in patients with sulfonamide allergies due to its structural similarity and potential for cross-reactivity.

questions.text: A pregnant woman undergoes ultrasound imaging which reveals excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid, diagnosed as polyhydramnios. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with polyhydramnios?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral renal agenesis

 

  • Bilateral renal agobgenesis, where both kidneys are absent in the fetus, is not associated with polyhydramnios; rather, it typically leads to oligohydramnios (too little amniotic fluid) because the fetal kidneys contribute to amniotic fluid production through urine output.
  • Without kidney function, there is insufficient fluid production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oesophageal atresia: This condition can lead to polyhydramnios because the fetus is unable to swallow and absorb amniotic fluid, leading to its accumulation.


Option C. Twinning: Polyhydramnios can occur in multiple pregnancies, especially with complications such as Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS), where one twin receives more blood flow and produces more urine, contributing to excessive amniotic fluid.


Option D. Microencephaly: Although not as directly linked as other anatomical abnormalities affecting swallowing, conditions that severely affect the central nervous system might impact the ability to swallow, potentially contributing to polyhydramnios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Conditions impairing swallowing or increasing urine output can lead to polyhydramnios, whereas conditions like bilateral renal agenesis that reduce or eliminate urine output lead to oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mirrizzi syndrome

 

  • Jaundice may ensue if the gallstone compresses the CBD (Mirizzi).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gall stone ileus: Rarely, a large solitary gallstone may erode the gallbladder wall, causing a cholecysto-duodenal fistula and subsequent bowel obstruction, known as gallstone ileus.

 

Option C. Choledocholithiasis: When gall stone slips into the CBD

 

Option D. Xanthogranulomatous cholecystits: It’s a histological diagnosis after cholecystectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mirrizzi syndrome is a stone in gall stone bladder/cystic duct causing compression of CHD/CBD leading to jaundice.

choices.text: It occurs when CD4 cell count is less than 50
Develops after initiation of anti-retroviral therapy
Associated with delayed type of hypersensitivity
Does not require specific antimicrobial therapy for recovery

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with a history of advanced HIV starts antiretroviral therapy (ART). After an initial improvement, the patient returns to the clinic with worsening clinical symptoms, suggestive of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). Which of the following statements about IRIS is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs when CD4 cell count is less than 50

 

  • Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) often occurs during the recovery phase after initiation of ART, as the immune system begins to recover.
  • It does not exclusively occur when the CD4 cell count is less than 50.
  • IRIS can happen even as the CD4 count rises, which results in an exaggerated immune response to previously acquired opportunistic infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Develops after initiation of anti-retroviral therapy: This is true; IRIS develops after the immune system begins to recover following the initiation of ART.

 

Option C. Associated with delayed type of hypersensitivity: This is true; the pathology of IRIS is related to a heightened immune response against opportunistic infections.

 

Option D. Does not require specific antimicrobial therapy for recovery: This is false; management of IRIS often involves the treatment of the underlying opportunistic infection alongside continued ART.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IRIS (Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome)
    • It occurs in some cases of AIDS during the recovery phase following the initiation of ART.
    • As the viral load decreases, the immune system begins to recover, CD4 T cell count rapidly increases
    • Which results in an exaggerated immune response to a previously acquired opportunistic infection causing an overwhelming inflammatory response, that paradoxically makes the symptoms of infection worse.

questions.text: A primigravida at full term reports feeling faint when lying down but experiences relief upon turning to her side or sitting up. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC (Inferior Vena Cava) compression

 

  • The symptom of faintness when lying down in a pregnant woman, especially in the later stages of pregnancy, is typically due to compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus when the woman lies on her back.
  • This position can decrease venous return to the heart, reducing cardiac output and subsequently leading to decreased blood flow to the brain, manifesting as faintness.
  • Turning to the side, especially the left side, relieves this pressure, improving venous return and alleviating symptoms.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Increased abdominal pressure: While it can cause discomfort, it does not specifically lead to faintness from lying down as directly as IVC compression does.

 

Option C. Increased intracranial pressure: This would not typically cause position-dependent faintness and is not related to positional changes during pregnancy.
 

Option D. After heavy lunch: Although a heavy meal might cause discomfort or drowsiness, it does not cause positional faintness associated with the supine position in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In late pregnancy, supine hypotensive syndrome caused by IVC compression by the gravid uterus is a common and important consideration for positional faintness.
  • Advising pregnant women to avoid lying flat on their backs and instead lie on their side, especially the left, can prevent these symptoms and improve venous return.

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain & temperature in trunk and limbs
Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from face
Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of palate

questions.text: A MRI of 60-year-old female reveals a defect in the territory served by the artery marked in given MRA. Which of the following features is not a component of the syndrome related to the vessel indicated by the yellow arrows:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense

 

  • Marked structure in the given MRA is Posterior inferior cerebellar artery which is a tortuous branch from vertebral artery.
  • It supplies the posterolateral zone of medulla.
  • Occlusion of which will lead to Lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome.
  • Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense is due to damage to medial lemniscus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature in trunk and limbs: Contralateral Loss of Pain & Temperature in Trunk and Limbs is a classic feature of Lateral Medullary Syndrome. The lesion affects the spinothalamic tract in the medulla, which carries pain and temperature sensations. Since these fibers decussate (cross over) at the level of the spinal cord, the deficit is observed on the side opposite the lesion.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from face: Ipsilateral Loss of Pain and Temperature Sensation from Face is consistent with Lateral Medullary Syndrome. The lesion affects the descending tract and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, leading to loss of pain and temperature sensation on the same side of the face as the lesion.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of Palate: Ipsilateral Paralysis of Muscles of Palate is also a feature of Lateral Medullary Syndrome. The lesion can affect the nucleus ambiguus, resulting in ipsilateral paralysis of the palate, pharynx, and larynx, leading to dysphagia, hoarseness, and possibly a deviation of the uvula away from the side of the lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the Lateral Medullary Syndrome due to a lesion in the territory of the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery, expect to find contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, and ipsilateral paralysis of the palate, but not contralateral loss of position and vibration sense, which is typically preserved.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has been experiencing unilateral headaches on the right side for the past five months. Physical examination does not reveal any significant abnormalities. A lesion is visible on the CT scan of her head, as shown in the accompanying brain image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meningioma

 

  • The tan-yellow mass identified is a meningioma, a benign neoplasm originating from the meningeal covering of the brain, specifically from the meningothelial cells.
  • The image appears to show a well-circumscribed lesion that is likely extra-axial, as meningiomas typically originate from the meninges, the membranes covering the brain.
  • They can compress adjacent brain tissue as they grow, leading to symptoms such as headaches.
  • Meningiomas usually present with a 'dural tail' sign on imaging, which is a thickening of the dura mater near the tumor, but the absence of other images precludes further detail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Astrocytoma: An astrocytoma typically presents as an infiltrative lesion within the brain parenchyma. The lesion shown in the image is well-circumscribed and does not display the diffuse infiltration characteristic of astrocytomas.

 

Option C. Ependymoma: These tumors often arise within the ventricular system or the spinal canal and are associated with the ependymal cells lining the cerebrospinal fluid pathways. The lesion in the image does not appear to be in the ventricles or central canal.

 

Option D. Metastasis: Brain metastases can appear as single or multiple lesions within the brain and often cause peritumoral edema which can be seen as a darker rim on CT images. The singular, well-defined nature of the lesion makes metastasis less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of neuroimaging, a well-circumscribed, extra-axial lesion, especially one that causes unilateral symptoms such as headaches without significant neurological deficits, is most suggestive of a meningioma.
  • Meningiomas are commonly benign and can be surgically resected depending on their size and location.

choices.text: apo A and apo E
apo E and apo B100

questions.text: In the context of lipid metabolism and liver function, which apolipoproteins are recognized as ligands for receptors that facilitate the hepatic uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) apo E and apo B100

 

  • Both apo E and apo B100 serve as ligands for the receptors involved in the uptake of LDL in the liver.
  • Apo B100 is directly involved in LDL particle binding to the LDL receptor. Apo E, on the other hand, also plays a crucial role by binding to both LDL receptors and other receptors such as the LDL receptor-related protein, facilitating the hepatic uptake of various lipoproteins including LDL.
  • Thus, both these apolipoproteins are key in mediating LDL clearance from the circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. apoE: ApoE alone is a ligand for other lipoproteins such as chylomicron remnants and VLDL remnants, but for LDL, it works in conjunction with apo B100.

 

Option B. apo A and apo E: Apo A is primarily associated with high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and is not involved in LDL receptor-mediated uptake.

 

Option D. apo B100: While apo B100 is a critical component of LDL and binds to LDL receptors, the question specifies the uptake involving both apo E and apo B100, recognizing the additional binding capacity provided by apo E.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The combined roles of apo E and apo B100 as ligands for the hepatic uptake of LDL, facilitates the clearance of this lipoprotein from the bloodstream and emphasizing the complexity of lipid transport and metabolism.

questions.text: An 8-month pregnant woman presents with severe pruritus and mild icterus. Her serum bilirubin is 3 mg/dL, and she has elevated AST, ALT and alkaline phosphatase but normal GGT levels. Renal function tests and coagulation profile are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy

 

  • Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) is a condition that typically presents in the third trimester with severe pruritus and can include jaundice. It is characterized by elevated bile acids in the liver, leading to symptoms.
  • The key laboratory findings include elevated bilirubin and liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, often with normal GGT, which helps differentiate it from other hepatic disorders.
  • The normal renal function and coagulation profile further support the diagnosis of ICP, as these typically remain unaffected in ICP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Viral Hepatitis: This condition usually presents with a more pronounced elevation in liver enzymes and often involves symptoms like fatigue, anorexia, and malaise, which are not mentioned here. Viral hepatitis also typically shows elevated GGT levels.

 

Option B. HELLP syndrome: HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count) is a serious pregnancy complication usually associated with pre-eclampsia and would typically include symptoms related to hypertension and abnormal coagulation profiles, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. Ascending cholangitis - This is an infection of the bile duct characterized by Charcot's triad of fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain, and would more likely show elevated GGT and signs of infection like leukocytosis, which are not indicated here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a condition characterized by severe pruritus, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes with normal GGT, typically presenting in the third trimester.
  • It is important to recognize and manage it appropriately to minimize risks to both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase can be regulated by all the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycogenin

 

  • Glycogenin is involved in the initial step of glycogen synthesis; it is an autocatalytic glycosyltransferase that glucosylates itself, thereby providing a primer for the addition of further glucose molecules by glycogen synthase.
  • It does not play a role in the regulation of glycogen phosphorylase, the enzyme responsible for glycogen breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: cAMP is a secondary messenger that is elevated in response to adrenergic stimulation and leads to the activation of Protein Kinase A (PKA), which subsequently activates glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option B. Calmodulin: Although not directly mentioned in the original text, calmodulin can be involved in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase kinase in the brain, which in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option C. Protein Kinase A: PKA, once activated by cAMP, phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase kinase, which then activates glycogen phosphorylase, promoting glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycogenin is associated with the initiation of glycogen synthesis and is not a regulator of glycogen phosphorylase, which is involved in glycogenolysis.

questions.text: Which organism is most commonly associated with transplacental transmission and subsequent microcephaly in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika virus

 

  • The Zika virus is known to be transmitted from mother to fetus via the placenta and is associated with a range of congenital anomalies, most notably microcephaly, where a baby is born with a significantly smaller head due to abnormal brain development.
  • The image does not directly identify the organism but gives a clue by indicating the pathology associated with microcephaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella virus: While Rubella can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes a spectrum of birth defects, it is not as strongly associated with microcephaly as Zika virus.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can lead to congenital CMV infection, which can result in a variety of neurologic abnormalities, but the hallmark congenital presentation isn't microcephaly as it is with Zika virus.

 

Option D. Parvo virus: Parvovirus B19 can cause hydrops fetalis and miscarriage but is not primarily known for microcephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Among the pathogens listed, the Zika virus is most strongly associated with microcephaly due to transplacental transmission.
  • Pregnant women are advised to take precautions against Zika virus infection, especially in endemic areas.

choices.text: Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH
Elevation in the level of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with irregular menses and hirsutism is diagnosed with Stein-Leventhal syndrome, commonly known as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Her hormonal profile is evaluated as part of the management. Which of the following findings is NOT typically associated with Stein-Leventhal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elevation in the level of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG)

 

  • Stein-Leventhal syndrome, or PCOS, is characterized by a hormonal imbalance where the level of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) is actually decreased, not increased.
  • SHBG binds to sex hormones, and lower levels are thought to contribute to the increased availability of free testosterone, which can exacerbate symptoms like hirsutism and acne.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH: This is a typical finding in PCOS, where the LH to FSH ratio is often elevated, which can lead to anovulation.

 

Option B. Insulin resistance: Many patients with PCOS exhibit insulin resistance, which is associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes and plays a role in the pathophysiology of the syndrome.

 

Option C. Elevation of plasma testosterone: This is a common feature of PCOS and contributes to the virilizing symptoms such as hirsutism and acne.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In PCOS (Stein-Leventhal syndrome), SHBG levels are typically reduced, which contributes to the increased levels of free testosterone.
  • This biochemical feature is important for understanding the pathophysiology and clinical manifestations of the syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with fever, malaise, and hepatomegaly. A liver biopsy is performed, and the histopathological slide is shown. Which disease is most likely associated with this histopathological finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Q fever

 

  • Fibrin ring granulomas, or doughnut granulomas, are a specific histopathological feature often associated with Q fever, a disease caused by Coxiella burnetii.
  • This organism is typically transmitted to humans through inhalation of aerosols from contaminated animal materials.
  • The granulomas are so named because of their appearance, with a central fat vacuole surrounded by a ring of fibrin, sometimes resembling a doughnut.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF): RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and typically presents with a rash that starts on the ankles and wrists and spreads to the trunk, petechial rash, and potential involvement of the lungs and heart. However, it does not typically present with fibrin ring granulomas.

 

Option C. Lyme disease: Caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through the bite of infected ticks. The hallmark sign of early infection is erythema migrans, a circular rash at the site of the tick bite, not associated with fibrin ring granulomas.

 

Option D. Ehrlichiosis: This bacterial illness is transmitted by ticks and can cause symptoms such as fever, malaise, and leukopenia. Histopathology typically may show leukocyte inclusion bodies but does not involve fibrin ring granulomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fibrin ring granuloma, also known as doughnut granuloma, is a histopathological finding that is characteristic of Q fever.

choices.text: Increased Anatomical Dead Space, Decreased Alveolar Dead Space
Decreased Anatomical Dead Space, Increased Alveolar Dead Space
Increased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space
Decreased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space

questions.text: A 63-year-old male on ventilator support with a long history of smoking and chronic bronchitis is undergoing evaluation for respiratory difficulties. His spirometry shows a significant reduction in forced expiratory volume, and a CT scan reveals emphysematous changes in the lungs. In this scenario, what would be the expected changes in both anatomical and alveolar dead space?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space

 

  • In a patient with chronic bronchitis and emphysema, as described, both anatomical and alveolar dead spaces are likely to be increased.
  • Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of air within the respiratory tract that does not participate in gas exchange, primarily because it remains in the conducting airways.
  • In conditions like chronic bronchitis, where there is chronic inflammation and possible airway dilation, the anatomical dead space can increase due to the enlargement of the airways.
  • Alveolar dead space refers to the volume of air within alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused sufficiently.
  • In emphysema, the destruction of alveolar walls leads to the formation of larger, irregular air spaces (bullae) and a loss of capillary beds.
  • This structural change results in increased alveolar dead space as more alveoli lack adequate blood flow for gas exchange despite being ventilated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Anatomical Dead Space, Decreased Alveolar Dead Space: Increased Anatomical Dead Space, Decreased Alveolar Dead Space - This choice is incorrect as emphysema typically increases alveolar dead space due to decreased perfusion of alveoli.

 

Option B. Decreased Anatomical Dead Space, Increased Alveolar Dead Space: Decreased Anatomical Dead Space, Increased Alveolar Dead Space - This is not consistent with the pathophysiology of chronic bronchitis or emphysema, both of which increase the airway size thereby increasing anatomical dead space.

 

Option D. Decreased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space: Decreased both Anatomical and Alveolar Dead Space - This is incorrect as both types of dead space increase in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In conditions like chronic bronchitis and emphysema, part of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), both anatomical and alveolar dead spaces are expected to increase due to changes in airway structure and alveolar destruction, respectively.
  • This increase in dead space can contribute to the inefficiency in gas exchange characteristic of these conditions, which is crucial for clinical assessment and management of respiratory support.

choices.text: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)
Body surface area (BSA)
Central venous pressure (CVP)
Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)

questions.text: In the management of a 63-year-old female with advanced heart failure admitted to the ICU for acute decompensation, characterized by significant shortness of breath and marked peripheral edema, the attending cardiologist contemplates advanced hemodynamic monitoring. Which of the following parameters, when integrated with clinical assessment, is pivotal in calculating the Cardiac Index and thus essential for tailoring an individualized treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Body surface area (BSA)

 

  • The Cardiac Index (CI) is a hemodynamic parameter that adjusts the cardiac output (CO) to the body size of the patient, providing a more precise measurement of the heart’s efficiency.
  • It is calculated by dividing the CO by the body surface area (BSA), yielding a value typically expressed in liters per minute per square meter (L/min/m²).
  • In the setting of acute decompensation in heart failure, accurately assessing the CI is critical for guiding therapy, as it reflects the heart's ability to deliver oxygenated blood to the tissues.
  • BSA is essential in this calculation to ensure that the patient’s size is accounted for in the assessment of cardiac function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP): Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) is indicative of left atrial pressure and can be used to estimate left ventricular end-diastolic pressure, but it is not directly used in the calculation of the Cardiac Index.

 

Option C. Central venous pressure (CVP):  Central venous pressure (CVP) reflects right atrial pressure and can provide information about fluid status but is not used to calculate the Cardiac Index directly.

 

Option D. Systemic vascular resistance (SVR): Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) is a measure of the resistance in the systemic circulation that the left ventricle must overcome to eject blood during systole. It is used in other hemodynamic calculations but not directly in the calculation of the Cardiac Index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Cardiac Index is a critical measurement in the management of heart failure, particularly during acute decompensation, and is calculated using cardiac output and body surface area.
  • It is essential for personalizing treatment plans and optimizing hemodynamic support in patients with heart failure in the ICU setting.

questions.text: Blockade of which of the following is NOT a mechanism by which antihypertensive drugs act?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ATP dependent K+ channels

 

  • Antihypertensive drugs typically do not act by blocking ATP-dependent K+ channels.
  • In fact, the activation of these channels, particularly in the cardiovascular system, can lead to hyperpolarization of the cell membrane and vascular relaxation, which can reduce blood pressure.
  • Some antihypertensive drugs, such as certain types of vasodilators, actually work by opening these channels rather than blocking them.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-adrenoceptors: Blocking these receptors is a common mechanism of action for antihypertensives. Alpha-blockers inhibit these receptors, leading to vasodilation and decreased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Noradrenaline release: Some antihypertensive agents, like beta-blockers and central alpha-agonists, work by inhibiting the release of noradrenaline, which decreases heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Option D. Beta-adrenoceptors: Beta-blockers are a well-known class of antihypertensive drugs that inhibit beta-adrenoceptors, leading to a decrease in heart rate and cardiac output, which lowers blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ATP-dependent K+ channels are not blocked by antihypertensive drugs.
  • Instead, some antihypertensives utilize the opening of these channels as a mechanism to induce vasodilation and lower blood pressure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes orthotopic cardiac transplantation. One month later, an endomyocardial biopsy specimen shows focal myocardial cell death with scattered lymphocytes and plasma cells. Which of the following pathologic processes best accounts for the biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rejection

 

  • The findings of focal myocardial cell death along with the presence of lymphocytes and plasma cells in a patient who recently underwent cardiac transplantation suggest an immune response against the transplanted heart, indicating transplant rejection.
  • This is a common and serious complication following organ transplantation and is characterized by the recipient's immune system attacking the donor tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmunity: This refers to the immune system attacking the body's own cells, which is not typically indicated by the presence of myocardial death in a transplant scenario.

 

Option B. Ischemia: Would generally not cause a significant immune cell infiltrate but rather would be suggested by necrosis with a lack of inflammatory cells.

 

Option C. Infection: While infections can attract immune cells, they would likely be accompanied by other signs or a different pattern of immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of lymphocytes and plasma cells in a biopsy after organ transplantation is indicative of rejection.
  • It is crucial to recognize the histologic signs of rejection in transplanted organs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department in comatose state. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 48 beats per minute, and rectal temperature is 34°C. Testing reveals hyponatremia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myxedema coma

 

  • Myxedema coma is the extreme manifestation of hypothyroidism, a condition marked by severe thyroid hormone deficiency.
  • It typically presents with symptoms such as hypotension, bradycardia, hypothermia, and altered mental status, including coma.
  • The hyponatremia in this patient likely results from the decreased renal water excretion due to the altered thyroid state.
  • The combination of these clinical features strongly points to myxedema coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome: This condition involves excessive urinary sodium loss caused by brain injury or disease, leading to hyponatremia. However, it does not usually present with hypothermia or a decreased heart rate, nor does it typically cause coma.

 

Option C. Opioid Poisoning: Opioid overdose can cause coma and respiratory depression, potentially leading to hypotension. However, bradycardia and hypothermia are less characteristic, and opioid poisoning does not typically lead to hyponatremia.

 

Option D. Diazepam poisoning: Overdose of diazepam, a benzodiazepine, can lead to coma and hypotension but is not commonly associated with severe bradycardia or hypothermia and does not explain the hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with coma, hypotension, bradycardia, hypothermia, and hyponatremia, consider myxedema coma, particularly if the clinical context or previous medical history suggests hypothyroidism.

questions.text: During an advanced airway management workshop, a resident is asked to select an appropriate laryngoscope blade for a patient with a known difficult airway due to cervical spine immobility. Which of the following laryngoscope blades is specifically designed to improve visualization of the vocal cords without the need for extensive neck manipulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) McCoy blade

 

  • The McCoy blade is a unique type of laryngoscope blade that features a hinged tip controlled by a lever on the handle.
  • This design allows the tip to be lifted, thereby elevating the epiglottis directly and improving the view of the glottis without requiring significant neck movement, making it ideal for patients with limited cervical mobility.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Miller blade: A straight blade used primarily for pediatric intubations or in patients with a long, floppy epiglottis, requiring more skillful manipulation to lift the epiglottis.

 

Option B. Macintosh blade: The most commonly used curved blade that slides into the vallecula, indirectly lifting the epiglottis to visualize the vocal cords, requiring some degree of neck manipulation.

 

Option D. Wisconsin blade: Similar to the Macintosh but with a slightly different curve, also requiring placement in the vallecula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the specific design and purpose of different laryngoscope blades is crucial for effective airway management, particularly in patients with known airway challenges.
  • The McCoy blade is particularly beneficial for patients where neck movement must be minimized, providing a safer approach to securing the airway.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of diabetes and chest pain, previously elevated troponin I, and recent antiarrhythmic treatment, now has a decreased ejection fraction of 28%. His current symptoms include reduced exercise tolerance, normal vitals, and lung crackles. Given these findings and the heart's gross appearance provided, the likely complication to develop is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Systemic thromboembolism

 

  • This enlarged and dilated heart has a large ventricular aneurysm.
  • The aneurysm most likely resulted from weakening of the ventricular wall at the site of a prior healed myocardial infarction.
  • Because of the damage to the endocardial lining, and stasis and turbulence of blood flow in the region of the aneurysm, mural thrombi are likely to develop.
  • When detached, these thrombi embolize to the systemic circulation and can cause infarcts elsewhere.
  • The reduced ejection fraction indicates poor cardiac output, which is often associated with stasis of blood, particularly in the left ventricle and atrium. This stasis can lead to thrombus formation.
  • In the context of the question, a patient with marked reduction in ejection fraction and symptoms of heart failure (evidenced by reduced exercise tolerance and crackles in the lungs suggestive of pulmonary edema) is at high risk for the formation of intracardiac thrombi, which can dislodge and cause systemic thromboembolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial myxoma: A benign tumor of the heart that could cause similar symptoms but is less likely than thromboembolism in a patient with low ejection fraction and heart failure symptoms.

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to compression of the heart. While this can be associated with reduced ejection fraction, it does not directly cause systemic embolism.

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Thickening of the pericardium leading to restricted heart filling. This condition would not directly lead to systemic embolism either.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A significantly reduced ejection fraction in the context of heart failure increases the risk of systemic thromboembolism due to blood stasis and potential thrombus formation within the heart.

questions.text: A research study is conducted in an urban slum in Mumbai which examined various potential risk factors for breast cancer in a group of 100 women. Based on the image shown below, how many risk factors are statistically significantly associated with breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2

 

Forest Plot (Blobbogram)

 

  • A graphical display of estimated results from a number of scientific studies addressing the same question, along with the overall results.
  • In the given question, 5 risk factors of breast cancer are chosen for evaluation – Milk consumption, early age of menarche, protein consumption, increasing age, family history
  • Each factor has OR given with confidence intervals
  • All 5 factors have OR >1 (Each factor has association present with breast cancer)
  • If confidence interval include 1 in its range (as seen in milk consumption, early age of menarche, protein consumption) it indicates insufficient evidence to conclude that the groups are statistically significantly different (or in this case association)
  • Hence, only 2 factors: Increasing age, family history have significant association with breast cancer

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A forest plot can be used to visually appraise the significance of associations in a meta-analysis.
  • Factors with CIs not crossing the null effect line (OR of 1) are considered to have a significant association.
  • In this study, only 'Increasing age' and 'Family history' are significant risk factors for breast cancer, as their confidence intervals do not include 1.

choices.text: Bone marrow/ erythroid precursor cells

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neurons

 

  • Neurons are the least affected by irradiation among the options provided.
  • This is because mature neurons in the central nervous system are post-mitotic, meaning they do not divide.
  • Radiation therapy targets rapidly dividing cells, which makes cancer cells particularly susceptible to damage.
  • Since neurons do not actively divide, they are less vulnerable to the effects of radiation compared to other rapidly proliferating cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spermatogonia: These are the precursors to sperm cells and are actively dividing. They are highly sensitive to radiation and can be easily damaged, leading to infertility.

 

Option B. Intestinal epithelial cells: The epithelium of the intestine is one of the most rapidly dividing tissues in the body, making it extremely sensitive to radiation damage, which can result in gastrointestinal toxicity.
