Option D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells: Bone marrow cells, including erythroid precursors, are highly sensitive to radiation due to their high rate of turnover and division. This is why radiation is a common therapy prior to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation—to ablate the patient's existing bone marrow and make room for the transplanted cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When considering the effects of irradiation, it is important to recognize that mature neurons are among the least affected cell types due to their non-dividing (post-mitotic) nature.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with recurrent urinary tract infections. A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is performed, revealing retrograde flow of contrast from the bladder into the ureters and renal pelvis. The radiologist notes picture as below. Based on these findings, which grade of vesicoureteral reflux does the radiologist most likely report?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade III

 

  • Mild to moderate dilation of the ureter and renal pelvis with minimal blunting of the fornices, without ureteral tortuosity, is characteristic of Grade III vesicoureteral reflux.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. Grade I: Reflux into nondilated ureter only, without dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces, which does not match the description given.

 

Option B. Grade II: Reflux into the renal pelvis and calyces without dilation, which lacks the additional detail of mild to moderate dilation and minimal blunting of fornices.

 

Option D. Grade IV: Reflux with moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces, which includes changes beyond those described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grade III VUR is associated with mild to moderate dilation and minimal blunting of the fornices, indicating a more significant reflux that may require surgical intervention, especially if associated with recurrent UTIs and renal scarring.
  • Treatment decisions are based on the VUR grade, patient age, and clinical presentation, often incorporating antibiotic prophylaxis, patient monitoring, and potentially surgery.

choices.text: M. indicus pranii
M. avium intracellulare

questions.text: During an infectious disease rotation, a medical student is asked about the origin of the Mw vaccine used in the treatment of leprosy and as an immunotherapeutic in bladder cancer. The vaccine is known to be derived from a non-pathogenic mycobacterium. Which bacterium is used to create the Mw vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) M. indicus pranii

 

  • The Mw vaccine is derived from a non-pathogenic strain of Mycobacterium, known as Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP).
  • This vaccine has been used as an immunotherapeutic agent in various diseases, including leprosy and as an adjunct to chemotherapy in bladder cancer.
  • It is not made from M. welchii (which is not a recognized mycobacterial species) or M. avium intracellulare, which is a group of bacteria associated with opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. M. welchii: This is not a recognized species of Mycobacterium. The name might be confused with Clostridium perfringens, formerly known as Clostridium welchii, which is a completely different genus of bacteria.

 

Option C. M. avium intracellulare: This complex includes two species of nontuberculous mycobacteria which can cause infection in humans but is not used to make the Mw vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MIP vaccine: A killed leprosy vaccine has been recently developed in India in 2018, using Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP).
  • Trials have shown that if the vaccine is given to people in close contact, cases can be brought down by 60% in three years.

choices.text: Give antibiotics and refer to a tertiary centre
Give antibiotics and re-assess in 3 days

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to a Primary Health Centre (PHC) with a history of fever and cough. On examination, the healthcare provider notes chest in-drawing and a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute. The child’s weight is recorded at 11 kg. Based on the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, what is the most appropriate step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give antibiotics and re-assess in 3 days

 

  • According to IMNCI guidelines, the presence of chest in-drawing in a child older than 2 months of age with a respiratory rate higher than the normal range for their age (in this case, greater than 40 breaths per minute for a child between 12 months to 5 years) is classified as pneumonia. The recommended management for pneumonia, which is not classified as severe, includes:
    • Administering a course of oral amoxicillin for 5 days to treat the infection.
    • Providing a bronchodilator if wheezing is present, also for 5 days.
    • Soothing the throat and relieving the cough with safe remedies.
    • Advising the caregiver to return if the cough lasts more than 14 days for tuberculosis assessment, or if there is a recurrent wheeze, to assess for asthma.
    • A follow-up visit should be scheduled in 3 days to reassess the child's condition.
    • Caregivers should also be advised on the signs that would warrant an immediate return to the healthcare facility.

 

This approach allows for treatment of the illness while monitoring the child's response to therapy, ensuring that any deterioration in the child's condition is promptly addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Only antipyretics are given: This would not be appropriate as the presence of chest in-drawing indicates a need for antibiotic treatment.

 

Option B. Refer to tertiary care: This would be necessary if the child had signs of severe pneumonia or other complications, which is not indicated in the given scenario.

 

Option C. Give antibiotics and refer to a tertiary centre: This would be the course of action if the pneumonia were classified as severe, or if there were other danger signs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A pediatric anesthesiologist is setting up for a procedure on a small child who will be breathing spontaneously during the surgery. The anesthesiologist chooses a specific anesthesia circuit to best support spontaneous breathing. Which of the following circuits is most appropriate for spontaneous ventilation in pediatric patients due to its low resistance and dead space?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mapleson F circuit

 

  • The Mapleson F circuit, also known as the Jackson-Rees modification of the Ayre's T-piece, is particularly suited for pediatric anesthesia.
  • It is favored for its low resistance and minimal dead space, making it ideal for small children who are breathing spontaneously.
  • This circuit allows for efficient removal of carbon dioxide while maintaining a stable depth of anesthesia, which is crucial in pediatric patients due to their unique physiological characteristics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mapleson A circuit: Mapleson A circuit is more efficient during controlled ventilation rather than spontaneous breathing, especially in adults.

 

Option B. Mapleson D circuit: Mapleson D circuit, used in adults , offers advantages in controlled ventilation but can be less effective than the F circuit in spontaneous breathing scenarios.

 

Option D. Mapleson E circuit: Mapleson E circuit is not used commonly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mapleson F circuit is particularly beneficial for spontaneously breathing pediatric patients, offering low resistance and reduced dead space, which are essential for maintaining effective ventilation and anesthetic delivery in small children.

questions.text: An old aged patient presented with worst headache of his life. NCCT head revealed acute SAH. MR angiography was performed. What is the diagnosis (arrow)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Berry aneurysm

 

  • The MR angiography shows a saccular outpouching from a cerebral artery, which is characteristic of a berry aneurysm, also known as a saccular aneurysm.
  • Berry aneurysms are the most common cause of non-traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which aligns with the patient's presentation of the "worst headache of his life."
  • These aneurysms are typically found at arterial branch points in the Circle of Willis and can rupture, leading to bleeding in the subarachnoid space, hence the SAH observed on the non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) of the head.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arteriovenous malformation (AVM) - AVMs are tangles of abnormal blood vessels connecting arteries and veins, which usually appear more complex on angiographic studies, with multiple feeding arteries and draining veins, not a singular outpouching as indicated by the arrow.

 

Option B. Cavernous hemangioma - A cavernous hemangioma is a vascular malformation that typically appears as a well-defined, lobulated mass on imaging, not as a saccular outpouching along the course of a vessel.

 

Option C. Fusiform aneurysm - A fusiform aneurysm involves the full circumference of the arterial wall and appears as a dilation of the vessel segment, not a berry-like outpouching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When evaluating a patient with acute subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) on NCCT head, a berry aneurysm should be considered as a potential cause, especially when an MR angiogram reveals a saccular outpouching at an arterial branch point.
  • Berry aneurysms are significant because of their association with SAH and the potentially life-threatening complications that can follow.

choices.text: Bilateral internal iliac artery ligation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, para 5, experiences excessive vaginal bleeding following the normal vaginal delivery of an intact placenta. Despite manual exploration, bimanual uterine massage, administration of intravenous oxytocin, and 0.2 mg of methergin intravenously, the bleeding continues. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Injection of prostaglandin F2α (PGF 2α)

 

  • The next step in the management of severe postpartum hemorrhage unresponsive to oxytocin and ergometrine (methergin) would be the administration of prostaglandin F2α.
  • This medication is effective in causing intense uterine contractions that can help control bleeding by compressing the bleeding vessels within the uterine muscle. Prostaglandins are often used when other uterotonics have failed to control postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Packing the uterus: While uterine packing can be used as a temporary measure to control bleeding, it does not address the underlying cause and is less preferable to pharmacologic interventions that actively promote hemostasis.

 

Option B. Immediate hysterectomy: This is considered a last-resort treatment for uncontrolled postpartum hemorrhage when all other measures fail, due to its irreversible nature and significant impact on the patient's reproductive future.

 

Option C. Bilateral internal iliac artery ligation: This surgical intervention is another last-resort measure aimed at reducing pelvic blood flow to control hemorrhage when less invasive measures have failed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the management of postpartum hemorrhage, if bleeding persists despite the use of first-line uterotonics and manual techniques, prostaglandin F2α should be considered before more invasive surgical options.
  • This stepwise approach helps preserve fertility and reduces the risk associated with more invasive procedures.

choices.text: Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon
The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon

 

  • Scleredema is a skin condition characterized by the thickening of the dermis due to the accumulation of mucin and increased collagen.
  • It is not typically associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon, which are more commonly linked to systemic sclerotic disorders such as systemic sclerosis.
  • Scleredema, on the other hand, is a distinct condition that may occur in association with diabetes mellitus, after a streptococcal infection, or with certain malignancies, but it does not involve the fibrotic and vascular symptoms seen in scleroderma, such as sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of skin on the fingers) and Raynaud’s phenomenon (color changes in the extremities due to temperature changes or emotional events).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Can occur in association with diabetes: This statement is true. Scleredema is often seen in individuals with poorly controlled diabetes, representing a well-established association between the skin condition and metabolic disorders.

 

Option C. The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal: This is also true. In scleredema, the dermal layer of the skin becomes significantly thicker due to the deposition of mucin and increased collagen production, making this a defining feature of the condition.

 

Option D. Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen: This statement is true. Scleredema can present with erythema (redness of the skin) and a peau d'orange (orange peel-like) appearance due to the thickening and textural changes in the skin surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon, distinguishing it from conditions like systemic sclerosis that involve these specific symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with fluctuating weakness and he complains of worsening weakness in the evening. He undergoes a CT scan, which reveals an anterior mediastinal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymoma

 

  • Thymoma is a tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus and is commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as myasthenia gravis.
  • Myasthenia gravis frequently presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day, particularly in the evening, as seen in this patient.
  • The presence of an anterior mediastinal mass on a CT scan strongly supports the diagnosis of thymoma, given its typical location in the anterior mediastinum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mediastinal B cell lymphoma: While lymphomas can present as mediastinal masses, they typically do not cause symptoms of fluctuating muscle weakness or specifically worsen in the evening. Lymphoma symptoms more commonly include fever, night sweats, and unexplained weight loss.


Option B. Retrosternal goiter: A retrosternal goiter extends into the mediastinum but primarily causes symptoms due to compression of nearby structures, such as difficulty breathing or swallowing, rather than fluctuating muscle weakness.


Option C. Small cell lung cancer: Although small cell lung cancer can present as a mediastinal mass and is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, the specific symptom of worsening muscle weakness in the evening is more characteristic of myasthenia gravis associated with thymoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fluctuating weakness that worsens in the evening in a patient with an anterior mediastinal mass is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis, often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: An elderly man sustains a burn injury to his hands. Over a few weeks, the burn heals without the need for skin grafting. Which factor is most critical for the rapid healing in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remnant skin appendages

 

  • The rapid healing of a burn injury without the need for skin grafting suggests that the damage was not full thickness, meaning that not all layers of the skin were destroyed.
  • Remnant skin appendages such as hair follicles and sweat glands contain stem cells that can proliferate and differentiate to regenerate the epidermis and dermis.
  • This regenerative capability is crucial for the re-epithelialization process, which is the restoration of the epidermis after a wound or burn.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Underlying connective tissues: While important for the support of new skin tissue, underlying connective tissues do not directly contribute to the rapid cellular regeneration necessary for healing superficial burns.

 

Option C. Minimal edema and erythema: Although reducing swelling (edema) and redness (erythema) is beneficial for healing, these are responses to injury rather than underlying causes of rapid healing.

 

Option D. Granulation tissue: Granulation tissue is part of the healing process, forming a new connective tissue and microscopic blood vessels during wound healing. However, its formation is a later stage in the healing process and not the most critical factor for rapid initial healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The remnant skin appendages containing stem cells are crucial for the rapid healing of partial-thickness burns, as they contribute to the regeneration of the epidermis.

choices.text: Massive hepatic necrosis

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency department with marked hematemesis lasting for 3 hours. On examination, he has a low-grade fever, a rapid pulse, rapid breathing, and hypotension. His abdomen is distended with a fluid wave, and the spleen is palpable. What liver disease is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cirrhosis

 

  • Cirrhosis of the liver can lead to portal hypertension, which in turn can cause the development of varices.
  • These varices, most commonly in the esophagus or stomach, can rupture leading to significant hematemesis, which is likely what has happened in this patient.
  • The fluid wave in the abdomen suggests the presence of ascites, another complication of cirrhosis.
  • A palpable spleen could indicate splenomegaly, also associated with portal hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholangiocarcinoma: A bile duct cancer that would not typically present with acute hematemesis or a fluid wave, which are suggestive of portal hypertension and variceal bleeding.

 

Option C. Massive hepatic necrosis: Would likely cause acute liver failure with signs like jaundice, encephalopathy, and coagulopathy, rather than isolated hematemesis and hypotension.

 

Option D. Fatty change: Commonly associated with steatosis, which is usually asymptomatic or causes vague abdominal discomfort, not the acute presentation seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cirrhosis can lead to complications such as portal hypertension, variceal formation, and rupture, resulting in marked hematemesis.
